EXPECT LEE TO
LEAVE TO DAY
State Department Officials
Speak of Returning
Consuls.
Recall of Representatives in
Cuba an Act of Precaution,
Not of Belligerency.
Before Their Departure thÂ« Consuls
Turn Over Affairs to tha
British.
Special Dispatch to The Call.
Call Office, Riggs House,
Washington. April 8.
The expectation of the State Depart
ment officials is that Consul -General :
Lee will be out of Havana before an- j
other sun sets in that city. This state- i
raent is based on the opinion of Assist- '
ant Secretary Day, who said this aft- '
ernoon that the Consul-General would
leave his post of duty probably to
morrow, on the Olivette.
A dispatch was received at the de
partment late this afternoon from Gen- '
eral Lee. but it was said it related sim
ply to a matter of detail of no gTeat
importance. From the fact that he
made no reference to any disturbance
or ill feeling, the officials take it for
granted that the day in Havana passed
by without anything of moment hap
pening.
By Sunday, at the very latest, it is {
now believed, all the Consular officers
of the United States in Cuba, and all
American citizens who desire to do so,
will have left the cities where they are
located and be either in the United
States or aboard vessels bound thither.
The effects of the Consulates, consist
tag of unimportant papers, furniture,
etc.. will be placed under the charge
of the Consular representatives of the
British Government now in the island.
where they will be kept pending the
developments of the issue between the
United States and Spain.
The important papers of the offices
will be brought to the United State*.
Officials of the State Department, in
discussing the withdrawal of the Con
suls from Cuba at this time, say it pre
sents many phases of interest. They
point out that such withdrawals must
not be considered in any manner a bel
ligerent act, but simply one of precau
tion based on humanitarian motives,
designed to protect them from any
trouble which might result from the
strained feelings between Spain and
this country- In a week, suggested one
official to-day, they may have returned
to their positions, if trouble between
the two countries should be averted.

ginger, quassia, wormwood, calamus
â¢ root, caraway and coriander seeds,
copperas, sulphuric acid, cream of tar
tar, alum, carbonate of notash ground
oyster shells, nux vomica, pierotum and
I strychnine.
WITHDRAWAL OF
AMERICANS FROM
PORTS OF CUBA
Consul Hyatt and Other Citizens
of the United States Leave
Santiago on the
Brookline.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, April B.â Thirty-two citizens of the UnitÂ£
States, among them Pulaski F. Hyatt, Consul at Santiago de Cuba, ana
Dr. Canalnero, superintendent of the Marine Hospital in that city, ar
rived this morning at Port Antonio on the Boston Fruit Company s
steamer Brookline, which was sent from here to get them by order of
the State Department in Washington.
Mr. Hyatt and a few of the passengers went ashore at Port Antonio,
and the Consul will come to Kingston to-morrow. The Brookline with
all the other refugees on board sailed for Boston this evening. The ship
was quarantined when she reached Port Antonio and held for several
hours, but the restrictions were finally removed because the authorities
realized the unusual circumstances.
Some of the Brookline's passengers, who went on to Boston, told
me that three Spanish warships were at Santiago when they left yester
day. Mines have been thickly laid in the harbor, they said, and the
Spanish authorities are taking every precaution to prevent the use of
Santiago as a place of landing by hostile troops.
I talked with Mr. Hyatt at Port Antonio, and asked him about his
orders. He told me that he had left his post because of instructions from
Washington. His withdrawal, he said, was not necessarily a prelimi
nary of war. It was in his opinion a step taken to prevent occurrences
that might lead to serious complications. Among the insurgents, he told
me, activity has been greatly increased because it is considered cer
tain that the United States is about to interfere and drive the Spanish
troops off the island. Mr. Hyatt says that in the vicinity of Santiago
the health of the people had been greatly improved since the relief sup
plies had been received from the United States.
Mr. Hyatt will remain here awaiting instructions from the State
Department. Word was received here to-day that the steamer Beverly
had sailed from Cienfuegos for Boston, stopping at Key West on the
way. She has on board Owen McGarr, Consul at Cienfuegos. and near
ly one hundred United States citizens. It is expected that to-morrow
at noon a steamer chartered by the American State Department will
leave here under orders to proceed to the southern coast of Cuba and
take off the United States Consuls and other Americans at four ports.
At the time this dispatch is filed the name of the vessel is not made
public, nor h: ye the destinations been made known.
REJECTS ALL
MEDIATION
At Least Premier Sagasta
So Declares in Be-
half of Spain.
But Certain Newspapers Are
Yet Hopelul of the Pend-
ing Negotiations.
Minister of War Corr?ro Declares
That Spanish Warships Must
Not Bo Surrendered.
Special Pispatch to The Call.
MADRID, April B.â Senor Sagasta
says the Spanish Government has no
intention of opening further negotia
tions. The Spanish Government to-day
remitted to Rome its full reply to the
Pope's suggestion of an armistice.
General Correro, the Spanish Minis
ter of War. in an interview this morn
ing, said: "Spain must not be alarmed
if war is declared and at the sinking of
Spanish warships. What we must at
all costs avoid is a Spanish warship
striking her colors to the American
flag. She should rather explode her
magazines. 1 wish to God Spain had
not a warship from Cuba to the penin
sula. We could then say to America:
'We are here, meet us when you
please.' "
The Liberal this evening says the
Government has decided to send a note
to the Pope, thanking him for his good
offices and begging him to persevere.
"But," the Liberal adds, "the Gov
ernment does not pledge itself to accept
the Papal decision."
The Heraldo will say: '"Spain re
mains in the same state of expectation
and uncertainty as yesterday. It is
impossible yet to give a definite opin
ion respecting the Pope's mediation
and the intervention of the great pow
ers."
The Epoca gives great importance to
the action of European powers inviting
', the Government not to assume a stiff
necked . attitude, since their interven
tion may be advantageous to Spain.
It thinks the key to the situation is in.
Senor Sagasta's hand, and. although
the Epoca is the paper which has
, fought most consistently lately against
: peace, it will say that the country does ;
not want war unless forced into con
flict-
Senor Gullon, the Foreign Minister,
' has held several conferences with the
Embassadors of the powers. Rumors '
â  have been circulated that the failure of ,
; the Pope's efforts was owing to the at
i titude of the United States. The Nun
ciature here has issued the following
note:
â¢'The Nunciature has to-day., higher i
hopes than ever of the success of the
papal intervention. It is not true that
President McKinley has repected th>>
Pope's intervention in favor of peace. !
Such impoliteness would be the more J
impolitic, not only because it would I
display a barbarous intolerance, but
because, however much any person
might be the Pope's enemy, it would b-Â»
Impossible to misinterpret the voice of
the venerable old man will recommend
the preservation of peace. On the other
hand.' the Catholics of North America :
â¢ would never pardon such a disregard of
'-â â  the vicar-genera! of their church S
The general tone of the evening'pa
pers is one of satisfaction at the in
terference of the European powers, as
showing that the latter realize Spain's <
! determined attitude against further
â  concessions to America. Some doubt
is expressed, however, as to the re
sult of intervention, lest the European
concert repeat the Cretan performance.
The concert has ' a weakness for 'â  the
stronger side, and may exact conces
sion from - Spain offensive to Spanish
pride and harmful to Spanish interests.
Therefore the papers warn the Min
istry to trust to Spain only.
El Correo Espana, the Carlisi organ,
publishes a letter from the Marquis Ca
vero. a Cartist general In the last war,
addressed to Count Xiquena. Minister
of Public Works. It is as follows: ~I
do not know your, president nor fellow
ministers. â  Therefore. I address you. of
fering my humble services in the hour
of the country's danger. I am taking
; this step without consulting Den Car
los or the party, owing to the urgency
iof the case. I was educated at the mili
tary college of Sasena, have held a
< cavalry command and seen battle fields,
jret I only ask. a rifle or an ax or a
footing on the first ship to meet the
enemy. Nor am I al'ne in this request.
There are thousands of CarliÂ«ts ready

CANNOT GET AWAY
FROM THE PHILIPPINES.
American Consul at Manila May
Have to Seek Safety at the
British Consulate.
NEW YORK. April B.â A Washington
special to the Herald says: The State
Department has received a dispatch
from the American Consul at Manila,
Philippine Islands, stating that he
could not obey the instructions of the
department to leave his post, because
there is no ship at the port sailing to
Hongkong. In case he should be un
able to get away before war occurs he
will be directed to place himself under
the protection of the British Consul.

ANTE-ELECTION SCANDAL.
Publics Accusation That a Certain
Teacher Pays Part of His Salary
to tha " Gang."
Bridal Dispatch to The Call.
SAN JOSE, April B.â No right-mind
ed, intelligent, decent citizen of San
Jose doubts that Boss Rea, Johnnie
Mackenzie and the adherents of these
manipulators of the corrupt political
machine of San Jose are responsible
for the dishonesty and extravagance in
the public offices of this city.
There is no question as to Rea and
Mackenzie being the head center of the
"gang" that has brought upon San
Jose high and excessive taxation, with
all its attendant evils â evils that have
throttled progress and prosperity.
Every man informed on political his
tory in this city, as it has been made
in the past few months, knows that
"Jim" Rea is responsible for the nam
ing of the candidates who appear on
the people's municipal ticket. Every
body endowed with the slightest politi
cal sense knows that every candidate
on that ticket, which has come to be
commonly designated as the "gang"
ticket, will be subservient to the wishes
of "Boss" Rea and Johnnie Mackenzie
if hÂ» is elected, whether it be to the
office "!" Mayor or as a member of the
appointing board. No secret is made
by the boss and his followers of the
fact that they are using every fair and
u'ifrur means known to astute politi
cians to bring about the election of the
men on the "gang" ticket.
With these facts clearly presented to
the people of San Jose they can have
no excuse for voting against their own
interests on next Monday. A vote for
any candidate on the "gang" ticket is
nothing less than a vote for Rea and
Mackenzie and a continuance of their
disreputable methods.
Reform, retrenchment, progress and
prosperity will come only by the elec
tion of men who are positively known
to have no alliance with the "gang"
and who are known to be under no ob
ligation whatever to the boss or any of
his satellites. Such men compose the
ticket of the New Charter Club. Back
of this ticket are the best citizens of
Pan Jose, in all ranks of life. Opposed
to it is the boss and all the vicious in
fluences that usually surround such a
man. Facts and reason are being used
by tho advocates of the New Charter
Club ticket to Becure its success. Fakes,
threats and misrepresentation are being
employed by the 'gang" in behalf of
the people's municipal ticket.
If the people of San Jose want the
highest office in their gift filled by a
man who has the respect of every de
cent man, who is honest, who is free
from any taint of the "gang," who has
n his ability as a business man
by the success he has attained in his
private affairs, who has never before
run for a public office, who has pledged
himself to administer the affairs of the
<ity on strictly business principles and
In conformity to the provisions and
spirit of the now charter, who has the
courage and the firmness of character
to carry out his promises, let them
vote for Sanford E. Smith for Mayor.
Tf the people of San Jose want the of
fice of City Clerk run as a public trust
and not as a haven of refuge for pets
of the "gang"; if they want to see
every claim against the city presented
to the Council in proper form, and, ac
cording to the provisions of the new
charter, showing its authorization and
Its legal verification; if they want to
Bee this office conducted with economy.
ency and full regard for the in
ta of the public, instead of being
F'lbservient to the class of creditors
vho are favorites of th? boss, and who
are engaged in " continual loot of the
pity treasury, they will vote for James
M. Allen for City Clerk.
Tf the pfv>ple of San Jose wish to pro
tect the city treasury from the raids of
the taxeaters; if thoy want a man in
the office of City Treasurer who will
he payment of all illegal war
runts because such payment would be
ii robbi v of the public, and not be
cause it micrht affect his nrivate purse
or ihar of his bondr-.nen; if they want
n man who will collect every dollar
that is due the city from licenses and
other legitimate sources and thus re
the people from high tax rates;
if they want an honest, tried and able
man t.< handle their finances, they will
vote for Joseph F. Colombet for City
trer.

posed of heavy taxpayers and success
ful business men; If they want able

Not less important for the people to
consider than any of the other offices
mentioned is the membership of the
appointing board. If the Mayor, the
Council, the Clerk and the Treasurer
control in a greater or less degree the
patronage, as far as the business of the
city is concerned, the appointing board
will control the patronage as far as it
applies to persons. Nearb- every ap
pointment to a position in the service
of the city will be more or less con
trolled by the members of the appoint
ing board. It i 3 for this reason that
the "gang" has bent every effort to get
at least a majority of the members of
this board.
If the people of San Jose want a fire
and police force made up of capable and
efficient men, selected because of their
qualifications, and not solely because
of their relationship to or friendship
with the appointing power or because
of their "pull" with the "gang"; if they
want to put a stop to scandalous re
ports of positions having been pur
chased on the police force; if they want
to put a stop to politics being done in
the public schools; if they want to de
pose Johnnie Mackenzie as an honorary
member of the Board of Education,
with his power of appointment greater
than all the regular members com
bined; if a qualification for the position
of school teacher is to be in all cases
competency and fitness and not money
or a "pull"; if "Jim" Rea is to be de

theimer, Thomas J. Riley, D. C. Vestal.
Political comment was largely taken
up to-day with the bold assertion by O.
O. Felkner that he had been informed
by a reliable person that one of the
male schoolteachers of San Jose was
paying $12 oO a month as on assessment
for the retention of his position.. With
this broad statement as a basis the
question is asked, Why does not the
Board of Education, which was so
quick to offer a reward of $500 the
other day for information that would
lead to the discovery of bribery in the
school department, take to investigat
ing instead of wagering?
If the Board of Education of San Jose
is really sincere in its desire to discover
and punish corruption in the depart
ment under its jurisdiction, it should, it
is claimed, take example from the
Board of Education of Los Angeles.
Let immunity from punishment be
promised the schoolteacher who has de
clared that he was "held up" and let.
him also be assured of being retained
in his position if he will make known
the name of the person or persons re
sponsible for this piece of corruption.
Let Rea and Mackenzie's Board of
Education institute a sweeping inves
tigation. It has the power to subp*ena
and swear witnesses. In order that the
atmosphere shall be entirely cleared of
the reports of corruption every teacher
and employe of the School Department
should be called before the board in
public session and examined as to any
attempt made by any person to extort
blood money from them. . Unless this
is done by the Board of Education that
body will be viewed with suspicion by
every decent, respectable man and wo
man.
The public accusation made by Mr.
Felkner Is of too serious a nature to be
put over as a mere campaign report.
The people are now demanding that the
probe of truth and honesty be applied,
that corruption, if any exists, be dis
covered and the cqrruptionists pun
ished. " **HÂ«a
Such a condition as is indicated by
the public stand of Mr. Felkner would
not be possible were San Jose not bound
in political slavery by Boss Rea and his
disreputable "gang." With the success
of the New Charter Club ticket on
Monday next will come an end to such
scandals as this and all others of a

How "Jim" Re does politics has
been well described by the afternoon
"gang" organ, which is certainly qual
ified to speak by the card. It thus tells
how candidates are "reached":
A man in business was elected to office.
He soon found that his business was in
creasing. He was pleased at his increased
prosperity. He found that he was taking
in several hundred dollars a month more
than he had been. He was on Easy street.
He was required to vote so and so ori
some proposition. He declined to do so
He was disciplined. How? The increase
in his trade was taken away from him
All those engaged in "doing" politics were
instructed to stop trading at his store
Word was passed down the line that be
was not "standing in." He found that be
made a mistake; that while consulting
what he considered to be the wishes Âf
the people he had neglected his own in
terests; that he was getting the worst
of it.
This unprincipled organ of an equally
unprincipled "gang" had the effrontery
to moralize on the foregoing in the fol
lowing language:
It is an old saying that the average
man can be reached through his pocket
that the man who puts principle above
pocket in political matters, as they re
late to municipal affairs, will come out
at the little end of the financial horn.
It follows with this damaging admis
sion of the cause of the "gang":
This is a state of affairs that has ex
isted in San Jose for a long time. The
i remedy was the passage of the new char
ter.
All this is but a prelude to booming
the candidacy of Charles J. Martin for
the Mayoralty. The evening "gang '
I organ says, speaking of Martin:
What can the politicians do to him? He
has no business that can be affected; he
has no grocery store or meat market, no
mercantile business to which patronage
could be directed and then removed for
disciplining purposes.
If any one wants to know how Mar
tin can and will be reached if he is by
any accident elected let hi.n obtain an
swers, but truthful ones, to these ques
tions:
Is not Martin a brother-in-law of L.
â¢ Lion, the head of the furniture firm
' that is now getting all of the "gang"
patronage in its line of business?
Are not the Lions among the most
active workers in behalf of the Rea
: ticket?
Did not Johnnie McKenzie, at a con
ference held at Del Monte, persuade
Martin to allow his name to be used at
the head of the "gang" ticket?
Is not Martin, In running for Mayor,
actuated more by what will accrue to
his relatives in the furniture business
than by his personal ambition or the
public welfare?
Will not Martin, in view of all the
facts here set forth, be under the influ
ence and control of the boss?
It is safe to say that none but af
firmative replies will be forthcoming
to each and all of these questions.
Under the circumstances can any
voter who is opposed to the "gang" and
its corrupt and extravagant adminis
tration consistently cast his vote for
C. J. Martin, particularly when there is
presented for his suffrage such an emi
nently fit man for the mayoralty as
Sanford E. Smith?
What is true of Martin Is also true
of J. W. Cook, the "gang" candidate
for City Clerk. Toth men are respect
able enough, but if elected they will
have to dance as the boss whistles. The
difference between these two men is j
that Martin will 'stand in" with the j
boss for the patronage that will go to |
the Lions, while Cook will "stand in" i
pimply for the emoluments of office
that will falls to him. Part of Cook's
obligation to the boss for the latter's
indorsement and support will be the
patronage of the Clerk's office. The
"gang" will be again allowed to name
at least three of the Clerk's five depu
ties, and the Clerk's office will continue
to be as expensive as It has been of
late.

all mistakes and pitfalls in this the
most momentous campaien ever car
ried on in the city of San Joseâ the

GRAIN AND GRASS
IN YOLO COUNTY.
Pasturage and Crops Doing Well and
Fruit Has Suffered but
Little.
WOODLAND, March 8. -^-Thirty-two car
loads of cattle and sheep have arrived in
Capay Valley. They were shipped from
Oceano, San Luis Obispo County, on ac
count of short grass and are the property
of E. Wieman. They will be pastured on
the Pace & Cramer range, near uumda
and Rumsey.
The first estimates of the loss of fruit
in Capay Valley on account of frosts
were no doubt exaggerated. A Call rep
resentative marie a trip through the val
ley this week. The damage has been con
siderable, but not so great as was sus
tained in other portions of the State. In
the northern portion of the valley the
orchards will yield nearly full crops, even
of apricots. In some orchards the worst
that the frost did was to save the owners
the labor of thinning out the fruit on the
trees. In other portions of the valley the
apricots and early peaches have suffered
badly, but there will be good crops of all
other and later fruits, especially prunes.
Nor are the grain crops in the valley suf
fering as in other parts of the county.
With the usual spring showers a large
number of the grain fields will yield
fairly well. Any section tnat can come
out of this exceptionally trying and dis
astrous season with fair crops of either
grain or fruit certainly demonstrates its
superior advantage*.
KILLED BY A BLOW
IN A PRIZE RING.
George Stout Dies From the Effects
of a Blow Delivered by the
Omaha Kid.
COLUMBUS, April B.â George Stout of
Philadelphia, who was knocked out by
Oscar Gardner, the "Omaha Kid," in a
hot fight last night, died from the effects
of the blow this morning. It was in the
twelfth round that the fatal jolt was de
livered, Stout falling heavily and never
regaining' consciousness. He was ordered
taken to the hospital by a physician, but
nothing could be done for him. A post
mortem examination is to be held to de
termine the cause of death. The knock
out blow was a short right swing on tne
jaw.
Gardiner was arrested, but was released
to-night under $700 bonds, pending his pre
liminary hearing. He is much distressed
over Stout's death, and says he will never
fight again. The other men who wore ar
rested after the light were released earl
ier in the day, it being found that they
could not be held on any charge, as the
Mayor had given permits for the fight.
STEEL FRAME CONSTRUCTED.
Progress of the Work on the Salinas
Sugar Factory.
SALINAS, April B.â The steel frame of
the main building at the Spreckels sugar
factory will be completed on Saturday,
within the ninety days called for by the
contract. Superintendent of Construction
G. R. Field claims that with the exception
of one Sunday not a day has been lost.
The interior of the building will be ready
for the placing of machinery during the
week. Work on the main office building
will be commenced this week. A sewer
system of four nines will be ready for
use by April 22.

street, sells "STANDARD" shirt*. â¢
SHOWS SIGNS
OF REFORMING
" Jim " Rea Attends an
Honest Political Gath
ering.
Visits a New Charter Club
Meeting and Hears Himself
Denounced.
Evila of Boss Rule Discussed Before
the Man Responsible for
Them.
Special Dispatch to The Call.
SAN JOSE, April B.â "Jim" Rea, at
tended by a son of Charles J. Martin,
the "gang" candidate for Mayor, and a
clerk of L. Lion, attended the tent
meeting of the New Charter Club to
night, at the corner of Seventh and San
Salvador streets, and was given an ob
ject lesson in decent politices. The
tent was crowded to its utmost capac
ity, and the boss stood up just back of
the last row of seats. Throughout the
meeting he displayed a state of ner
vous uneasiness which was easily
measured, by those who know his pecu
liarities, by the amount of "fine cut"
he consumed. He was the cynosure of
all eyes. Every reference to him and
his men and methods met with the
wildest applause, and the speakers
were not at all chary of expressing
themselves in unmistakable terms.
S. E. Smith, the candidate of the New
Charter Club for Mayor, was chair
man. He said that Monday would de
cide whether the city government was
to remain in the hands of the machine
or was to be placed under control of the
friends of the new charter. He pre
dicted a sweeping victory all along the
line by handsome majorities.
W. E. Crossman, candidate for Coun
cilman of the First Ward, said that it
was his firm belief that at the election
on Monday every precinct in the city
would give a majority for the New
Charter Club ticket from top to bottom.
F. B. Brown remarked that he did
not expect to be able to convert any
"thoroughbred" or any one upon whom
the "gang" had strings, even if they
attended the campaign meetings of the
Charter Club, but he did hope to con
vert to the principles of good govern
ment every sensible and right-minded
voter.
O. O. Felkner said that he noticed
that "the head of that corrupt gang"
was present; "but I am not afraid of
him," he continued, "and I shall say
plainly what is in my mind."
He then paid his compliments to the
boss, his henchmen and the evils they
have brought upon San Jose. In con
clusion he advised the people to vote
against boodle and misrule.
J. M. Allen, the Charter Club candi
date for city clerk, reviewed the situa
tion and declared that if he were
elected the people could rest assured
that no boss, no ring nor anybody else
would control him.
W. G. Alexander, one of the candi
dates for membership on the Appoint
ing board, made a plea in behalf of
good government, which would come,
he declared, only by the election of the
New Charter Club candidates.
Colonel W. B. Hardy asserted that if
the New Charter Club ticket was elect

Workmen Grand Lodge.

candidate for Councilman at Large and the
anti-boss candidate against "Jim" RÂ£a,
â¢was unanimously elected a corporate di
rector of the Grand Lodge Ancient Order
of United Workmen at its session
yesterday (Thursday), he having received
nearly the 380 votes of said grand lodge,
and being the only representative outside
of the grand officers elected to the office.
The high regard of the representatives for
Mr. Jarman, and their sympathy and as
surance for him In his noble and brave
fight to down "bosslsm." were the potent
factors which led to his election, an honor
'of no small nature, and one which none of
"Jim" Rea's followers would be granted.

J. B. CHURCH,

PANAMA CANAL
COMMISSION RETURNING.
International Representatives Much
Pleased With the Present Eco
nomical Management.
Copyrighted, IS9B, by James Gordon Bennett.
PANAMA, April B.â After nearly a
month's work Inspecting the Panama
canal, the International Commission
sailed to-day for Europe, via New York,
on the steamer Allianoa. On the report
of this commission depends largely the
future of the Panama Canal project.
There is good reason to believe that the
commission was favorably impressed with
what its members saw. The present
economical system, in wide contrast to
the reckless extravagance of previous
administrations, particularly attracted
the attention of the commlsion.

CRUSHED BENEATH THE
WHEELS OF A TRAIN
Rail Accident Which May Cort Â«
Calistoga Laborer His
Life.
NAPA, April B.â George Ackerman wasl
brought to the Napa County Infirmary
here to-day from Calistoga by Henry;
Clark, night watchman at that place.
Ackerman was run over by a train last
night and both of his legs were crushed.
He was under the influence of liquor
when the accident occurred.
Ackerman said there was another man
with him, and that the train struck both
of them, but the other man did not get
hurt.
County Physician E. Z. Hennessey dfr*
cided that amputation was necessary,
and Ackerman's left leg was taken off at
the knee and the right foot removed
above the ankle. It is thought the pa
tient cannot live.
Ackerman is about 61 years of age and,
a native of Switzerland. He has lived In
Calistoga for many years and is a la->.
borer by occupation.
SAUSALITO'S ALARM
â¢ SYSTEM DESTROYED.
Mechanism Stolen From the Firej
Boxes and False Alarms Sent
In By Miscreants.
SAUSALITO, April B.â The fire-alarm
system recently put in by order of tha
Town Trustees is in a deplorable condi
tion. An inspector has reported to tha
Trustees, after a careful examination,
that he could not find one box in the en-Â»
tire system that had not been damaged op
wholly destroyed, evidently by mischiev
ous persons. Glasses in the alarm boxes
have been knocked out and broken and in
some instances the inspector found where
the alarm cranks had been wrenched en
tirely out of place and the mechanism de-Â»
stroyed. One box has disappeared en*
tlrely.
The Trustees will undoubtedly make an
investigation, and an effort will be made
to discover the persons who have wrecked
the system, which was. put in at the
town's expense. Many false alarms hava
been turned in and the system outrage
ously abused.

PRISONERS IN THE ARCTIC ICE.
NO definite news concerning the whalers im-
I prisoned in the ice of the Arctic could fail to be
' of interest. Such a story, told with simple yet
graphic detail, The Call is able to present this morn
ing. It is the story written by TiHon, the man who
was commissioned by these castaways to bring a mes
sage to civilization. That he undertook a journey in
volving great peril, that he brought news of impor
tance, there can be no denying. This news has been
secured because investigation showed it to be of great
importance: in its way, unique. â¢No such journey as
it records, with such a purpose, was ever before un
dertaken. At least no such journey was ever com
pleted until now.
The actions o! TUton after he reached the civiliza
' r which ..'. so bravely striven were sur
ist 1 - evident heroism, which
H I to have been a - He deported himself
t .^ i create the mv. I &sok object was
formed that he was
said lie bore not what
terted it to be. It was a gratification to ascer
tain that however far Erom correct Tilton'a attitude
had been, his . that he declared it to
be \ â  picturesque and
rail of t â¢-. people had waited n-.onths to
obtain . more 1 ... ttive has
for >c;.:- I een laid before the readers o: any paper.
THE CONCERT OF EUROPE.
formal joint address made by Austria.
France. Germany, Great made by and Rus
â¢y. Great Britain, Italy and Kus
sia to our Government and to that of Spain
urging an agreement between them that will secure
the maintenance of peace and re-establish order in
Cuba is the latest development of that new factor
in diplomacy known as the European concert. It is
another step in the direction of making all interna
tional complications the subject of concern to all
nations, and as such it is of much more interest as a
precedent likely to be followed than a? a serious
effort to prevent the impending war.
As a matter of fact it is doubtful if any of the Em
bassacors who went in due state to present the ad
dress to President McKinley had any idea that his
course would be in the slightest degree affected by
what they would say to him on behalf of their Gov
ernments. European diplomatists, however, have
now acquired the habit of talking in concert and our
controversy with Spain presented too good an op
portunity for further talk in that way for them to
overlook it. They made their address in the interests
of peace in about the same way they would go
through any ordinary state function, and took good
care to ask of us nothing that would have required
anything more than a diplomatic nothing in reply.
Had the European powers seriously entertained the
idea of an interference by the concerted action in
this instance they would probably have found them
selves as hopelessly incapable of agreeing as they
were for many months in the contest between Greece
and Turkey. From all reports that have come to us
it appears that France sympathizes with Spain be
cause of her relations to the Spanish people and her
investments in Spanish bonds. The Germans are on
the same side because just now they feel aggrieved
at the United States because of the Dingley' tariff and
the increasing export of American farm products to
Germany. The Crar of Russia is on the side of the
Spanish crown on general principles, while Austria
would support it because the Queen-Regent of Spain
is a Princess of the Austrian house, r In the mean
time Great Britain, for many reasons, is decidedly
sympathetic with the United States just now, and it
would be a very sure thing that she would not agree
to any programme that would antagonize this country
in the least.
Fortunately the affair in itself is not one of. any
considerable importance. The European concert has â 
made its display and performed its function on the
stage with just enough pomp and action to show that
it is still alive. In the future (he precedent now set
may lead to some more vigorous effort? of the kind.
There may be an actual attempt on the part of
FurÂ« to interfere in American affair?. It will then
be seen whether it would be possible to ally all
Europe against us and whether we would be checked
on our course even it such an alliance should be
formed.
* If the gentleman who says he found $18,000,000 on
Â»n island can produce the coin later to substantiate
his story, the Klondike mining business might as" well
drop out of the competition. True, there is gold in
the Klondike, but the 'most ardent searcher after i:
dcÂ«Â« cot expect to Â»hovel it up ready minted i
THE PRESIDENT'S COURSE.
""T^HE great issues of war and peace are too grave
concerns to be treated from a partisan or a per
* sonal standpoint. They affect the national
honor and the welfare of the whole people.
In modern times no war has been either made or
avoided by a nation without criticism, usually unjust,
of those in authority, who see and know all sides
of every contingency. France was convulsed with the
war spirit in i8;o. and her Emperor had the choice
of domestic revolution or martial enterprise abroad.
Choosing the latter, he plunged into it without pre
paration and late unrolled the record of disaster from
the first skirmish to Sedan and the decheancc. Greece
wanted war, and forced the Government to it with an
army that had nothing to fight with but the historic
glories of Marathon. Salamis and Lepanto.
History is full of instances in which zeal has sub
stituted preparation for war with resulting disaster
and humiliation.
In current history these incidents are in course
of repetition; It for the purpose of partisan advan-
tage the country had been excited into war six or
three months ;iÂ£i> the enterprise would have embarked
entirely without preparation. Yet some papers and
some politicians were urgent for immediate war. If
they had had their way the opening would have been
disastrous. Of course, in the long run. the country
would have equipped its army and navy and closed
the struggle in honor and victory, but the expen-
diture of life and treasure would have been doubled,
Then the minority politicians, who are using patriot-
ism as a campaign stalking horse, would have made
the welkin ring with accusation against the Presi-
dent for disaster they had caused by their unfeeling
prostitution of popular loyalty.
During the Civil War President Lincoln had to
ftand the bitter blame of every disaster, and yet
nearly every move that failed was hotly urged by the
very classes that abused and derided him when fol-
towutg their demands brought defeat.
President McKinley is no tyro in statesmanship or
war. His patriotism and courage were put to a test
that was not tried by most of the men who profess
to soe something covert and cowardly in his patient
preparation to avoid the worst by being ready for it.
He followed and fought for the flag in many an
Â«ction and won his promotion before he readied his
majority. In considering strategy and preparation
he is equipped with a full experience in practical war.
He knows that battles are not won by perfervid
oratory, that powder is needed and not periods, rams
not rhetoric, and he knows that the beginning of
failure is in underestimate of the enemy. Spain is
poor and in decadence, but when even such a nation
coo* to war it is to fight, and no other, no matter
how great its inherent strength, can go out to meet
it unprepared.
In the last eight weeks we have put our strength
on land and sea in equipment for military use. We
have money, men and ships; we have guns and pow
der, an organized commissary, transportation in
order and stand at attentian. ready for what is to
come. If now diplomacy force Spain to see herself
as she is. and she remove our cause for reprisal, this
country will have a valuable experience, and in future
the mouth-valiant warrior will set his bueca! squad
rons in the air and invoke Mars to windy war in
vain if the country feel either lack of cause or need
of preparation.
The eyes of the people are on the men who will
attempt to gain partisan advantage out of such a
serious issue as slaughter, for if war come they will
be the first to hamper and impede the President, and,
as their kind have done before, keep a fire in the rear
more galling than that in front.
It is for Congress to declare war and for the Presi
dent to wage it. He knows his responsibility and has
prepared for it. No point has been lost while the
torrid Hotspurs have found it difficult to restrain their
desire to see somebody else fight. The President is
a soldier and knows his duty and will do it.
He should not fail, however, to give due weight to
the public impatience which has followed the an
nouncement that military prcpar-.tions are complete.
He will thereby deprive the political minority of the
chance to make capital and embarrass him by even
temporarily alienating the public confidence in his
course. In such a straggle as seems imminent the
President must not permit any shadows between him
and the people, for the partisan opposition in Con
groK will make of them substance, if pretentious
statement can do it. Since the speech by Lentz of
Ohio it is evident that the minority intend to s.v
the patriotic expectations of the people by voting
war budgets and make party capital by criticizing the
expenditure of the money. With a substantial frank
ness of relation established between the President and
the people these misplaced manifestations of par
tisanship will excite only disgust, for the people never
patiently endure the effort of politicians to turn
battle-shed blood into efnee-seeking advantage.
THE CASE OF LIEUTENANT ADfIMS.
TO state the matter concisely. Lieutenant Adams
has been drunk again. As an individual his
bibulous tendency might be of no general im
portance, but as a portion of the r.avy on a jag Adams
invites attention. The country has a right to demand
that the men who sail its ships shall be sober. Just
at a time when the country seems on the verge of wnr
and any man or officer may be called to instant dun
there can be no excuse tor keeping dipsomaniacs on
the roster.
But a short time ago Adams wa? tried for intoxi
cation. The court-martial found that the charge was
truf, but it also found a technicality by which it could
protect the accused from any penalty, and it did so.
*:" r this the tribunal was severely arraigned by the
Secretary of the Navy. The intimation was strong
that it had been wrongfully lenient toward an of
fender deserving 61 punishment. It might have been
supposed that this narrow escape would have been a
- to Adams, but hardly had he beer, restored to
duty before he got drunk again, gloriously full, and
was taken in disgrace to his quarters. New if the
court-martial whitewash him once more it will be
arraigned not only by disgusted officials, but by the
people at large.
The personnel of the navy is up to a high standard.
Citizens who pay for the navy, who pay for the train
ing of its men. would have it kept so. They have a
pride in it and a confidence which cannot be safely
abused. In the capacity of a private person Adams
would have peculiar facilities for indulging in his
amusement of painting his environment, with nothing
to interfere save the police. He should seire the op
portunity and resign. Failing to resign, he should
be dismissed.
There is in use at the per.itenyary of Colorado what
the Warden terms a "spanking chair." The person
occupying it gets automatically padded. and with
great rest. There is a feeling among the ultra-war
like that the Warden ought to lend the contrivtnee
to the Speaker pi the House.
THE SAN FRANCISCO CALL, SATURDAY, APRIL 9, 1898.
THE ISSUE IN SAN JOSE.
THE municipal campaign in San Jose virtually
closes this evening. The great mass of citizens
have taken their stand on one side or the other,
and are lined up for the contest on election day.
About all that can be advanced in the way of argu
ment has been set forth, and such voters as are still
in doubt which cause to support at the polls are
either persons of vacillating mind, whose actions are
always determined by the latest influence brought to
bear upon them, or else persons who are habitually
indifferent to public affairs and vote capriciously as
the impulse directs when the time comes.
A canvass of the citizens justifies the belief, that the
victory at the polls will be gained by the advocates
of good government, even if all the vacillating and
indifferent crowd should be herded by the boss and
his gang between now and the election. Nevertheless,
it is gratifying to note that the progressive and honest
clement of the people do not intend to take chances.
They have warned the people against the machinations
of the ring machine and put them on guard against
j the slanders and lies that are pretty sure to be issued
by the unscrupulous foe with which they have to
j deal. These warnings cannot fail to counteract to
| some extent the base methods resorted to by the
i gang candidates and their supporters, and the election
morning canards will be less potent in determining
j votes than the boss expects.
i This address of warning issued by the Charter Club
j at its last mtvt'ng was a natural and necessary out-
I come of the campaign itself. In all political contests
\ there is more or less of misrepresentation, falseness
and calumny, against which the public has to be
put on guard in the interests of honorable men. In
the San Jose campaign, however, that form of at
tack has been carried to a degree of lying almost be
yond precedent. An element of personal malice has
been infused into the attacks made upon nearly all
j the candidates of the Charter Club, anc the lies cir
| culated about them have had all the poison that mean-
ness and malignity can instill into the slander that un
scrupulous cunning invents and shameless mendacity
utters.
Eliminating the lies of the gang from consideration,
the issue presented to the voters of San Jose in this
election is in the fullest sense a question of honest
government and all the prosperity it implies against
dishonest ring rule and all the plunder, waste and
municipal stagnation that go with it.
THE ACCEPTED STREETS.
WE are enabled this morning to make the sur
prising announcement that the Board of Super
visors has at last completed arrangements for
the repair ot the streets and crossings of this city which
during the past thirteen years have been paved with
bituminous rock. At a meeting of the Street Com
mittee on Thursday it was resolved to advertise for
proposals with this end in view. The specifications
submitted require the contractor within three months
after the award to place all bituminous streets in per
fect order, and to thereafter keep them in that con
dition. Upon forty-eight hours' notice even" break
must be repaired.
This movement is quite startling, for the reason
that the Supervisors lor over ten years have appar
ently assumed that bituminous rock pavements were
going to last forever. The material came into ex
tensive use about ISSS. In that year several blocks
were laid on Golden Gate avenue. Some of them
immediately wore out: that is to say. no sooner had
the contractors laid them than they cultivated a dis
j position to generate "chuck" holes. This was attrib
. uted to the poor quality of the bitumen used, and
I orders were passed by the Supervisors boycotting the
product of the offer.ding deposits.
But no one ever suggested that measures should
be taken to keep other blocks of the material in re
pair. We believe that one over-zealous Street Super
intendent did persuade the Supervisors that the city
ought to have its own steam kettle and roller, but in
purchasing the machines somebody blundered and got
them so large it was found impossible to operate
them. As we recall the incident, the roller was too
heavy to be moved by the delicate muscles of the
-itive gentlemen who are employed by the Street
Department to repair accepted streets.
At the present time there are in the city over
13.000,000 square feet of bituminous rock pavement,
all of which is in a more or less bad state of repair.
: Especially on the downtown streets the material has
shown it? inability to sustain heavy traffic without
! constant attention. Although it is a nineteenth cen
; tun- marvel that for upward of thirteen years the Su
pervisors should have left the bituminous streets of
the city to care for themselves, the announcement
that a repairing contract is about to be awarded
comes, a> â â¢ye have said, in the nature of a surprise.
The fact that the city's business is always managed
with marked imbecility is. not the only ground for
â  amazement. Heretofore repairing has been done by
a force employed by the Superintendent of Streets.
Of course this means that no repairing has been done
at all. A public contract will displace these politi
cians. How it has been brought about, therefore, is
a mystery.
We perceive in this chapter of municipal history
two or three remarkable things. First, there is a
reversal of the policy of letting the accepted streets
gq to the devil: second, there is a covert attempt to
interfere with the leisure of the politicians employed
by the Street Department, some of whom will now be
compelled to go to work: thirdâ and more surpris
j ing than all â somebody is going to try to keep the
accepted streets in repair. We are scarcely able to
comprehend ill this. We fear there is a job be
hind it.
The proposition to have crazy criminals confined in
a penitentiary building will not be approved of by
the sane lunatics who make a specialty of committing
crimes and then getting excused on the plea o: being
peculiar. Where is the virtue of pleading insanity
and then having to go to jail after all?
Detailed accounts of the plans by which the ships
of the navy are to be distributed in case of war lack
in a measure the evidences of authenticity. As a rule
the initial move of the commander is not to confide
in the first correspondent who happens to come
along.
The Spanish Consul at Key West is said to con
template placing himself under the protection of the
British Consul there. Such precaution will not be
necessary. The residents of Florida have the honor
to be civilized.
A supposition that upon arrival in this country Lee
would have something startling to tell grows weaker.
It has even reached such a stage of incredibility that
the New York Journal accepts and pub'. ; .<'"?s it as a
fact.
Cranks Â»re becoming thick at Washington, but hap
pily few of them are in public life.

A gent leman
wished to have
the fence around
his garden paint
ed the other day,
bo he employed
an artist of the
sort whose work
EVEN HEAVEN
SEEMS
AGAINST HIM.
is judged by its extent rather than by its
artistic qualities, and telling him to go
ahead ard paint as his taste suggested,
left the man of pots and brushes 10 mirk
his will while the owner of the property
started for the races. On his way to In
gleside hornet a beggar with a blue pate 1 :
over his eye and gave, as he thought, a
nickel. Later on he discovered it was a
live-dollar piece. Arriving at the track,
he bought a ticket of admission from v
fellow with a black and blue eye, and ie
ceived among his change a bad quarter.
He started down the line picking to win
five losers out of six races, and in the
s'Xth race he only played a horse to
show; the dog was left at the post. Ev
ery one of the jockeys on the entire s-ix
horses wore blue colors.
He left the track, and, after taking din
ner down town, tried to retrieve himself
at poker. He bought three stacks of
blues in quick succession, and got rid of
them with even greater rapidity than he
acquired them. Then he went home and
went to bed after a day's sport that had
cost him exactly $530 75. In the morning
when he awoke and looked out of his win
dow the first thing that met his eye was
his fence, clothed from pillar to post in
a bright new coat of light blue paint.
The shock was something terrible, but
he has succeeded in recovering suffi
ciently to promise a sensational murder
when the artist presents his bill for col
lection. In the meantime he looks at the
sky through smoked glasses.

BATTLE OP THE BOOKS.
Editor Call: In your paper recently
i-.r.der caption of "The Battle of the
Books,** you say: '"As a matter of fact
the better part of all teaching cornea from
the teacher and not from books." That
is true, but 1 think there has been a ten-
Oancy of late years to carry the principle
ADYEBTISEMXNTS.
To the Klondike.
L. N. McQuesten, the>" Father of Alaska, writes :
"The ROYAL is the only Baking Powder
that will endure the severe climatic changes
of the Arctic Region* A miner with a can
of bad baking powder is almost helpless in
Alaska* Therefore, we have used nothing
but Royal Baking Powder/*
ROYAL B.*jq\a PgWOSS Â«X SEW Y33*.
too far. Too much importance has been
laid upon the question of how much mere
learning a pupil will acquire in school. It
is true that a pupil will learn more from a
good teacher than from the best of books,
and the knowledge of this fact tends to
lead educators- to attach too much impor
tance to the teacher as a source of in
struction independent of books, or at
least to underestimate the value of books.
If the true purpose of teaching were
merely to cram the mind with knowledge,
then that system that would impart the
most knowledge in a given time would
seem to be the best. But the gaining of :
knowledge is not the sole object. Of at
least equal importance is the development
of mental puwers and the formation of
good habits. The pupil cannot be a pupil ;
always; cannot always have the help of a I
teacher. He should be taught to rely i
upon himself, to stand alone. When he
leaves the school room his work is not I
done; he is only just entering upon the !
actual business and duty of life. He does j
not learn in school all that he should i
learn, however excellent his teachers and j
their system. To succeed in life, to ac- j
complish anything of value, he must be j
progressive, must continue to learn; and j
he must do this without either the spur
or the aid of a teacher.
To this end his course of instruction and
training in school should be such as
would not make him dependent upon his
teachers. He should be taught to learn
without their aid. He should have de
veloped in him a love for learning that
should cause him to desire it for its own
sake and his own good, and should have
habits of industry and thoroughness and
a feeling of self-reliance that would lead
him to active and persevering work on
his own account. His school should not
be regarded as a place where his work is
completed, but as an apprenticeship in
which he learns to use the best tools in
the best way for the work of his lifetime.
â¢No man ever accomplished anything or
amounted to anything whose improve
ment and development ended with his
school life.
Of all means of improvement at com
mand tht most valuable are books. These
are storehouses of all knowledge, upon
all suojects, always within our reach and
always at our service. Pupils in school
should be taught to use them and be
taught how to use them to the best ad
vantage. This should be one of the main
objects of the teacher. No matter how
great his capacity for imparting knowl
edge directly from himself, he can give
his pupils no instruction of equal value
to that which teaches them to make the
best use of books. The pupil who leaves
school with a love for books, trained to
make the best use of them, and with the
courage, industry and perseverance to dig
into then and lay hold of their treasures,
has an education that is immensely valu
able, which will lead him continually
farther and higher in the ways of life:
but, without this, no matter "how high
his standing in this, his acquirements are
destitute of life and vigor, temporary,
and of comparatively little value. He
lacks the vitality essential to progress
and growth. One cannot stand still after
leaving school; he must either grow or
dwindie.
The pupil at the beginning must of
necessity depend upon the teacher. As
he advances he should become more and
more independent of support. His text
books, especially in the higher grades,
should contain substantially all that he
is required at the time to learn, and in
such form that it can be learned from the
books themselves. And. while it is true
that there is no royal road to learning,
yet the book? should, as far as practic
able, present their subjects in a clear ana
attractive manner, so that the student
should be led to regard books not as
conundrums or task masters, but as
friends and helpers. The teacher should
guide and encourage tue pupil, not so
ihuoh with a view to giving the informa
tion sought as to building up habits of
application, perseverance and self-reli
ance, so that in the end the pupil may be
able ajid willing to walk alone. As a re
suit pupils, on leaving school, might not
have so large a knowledge as might
otherwise be crammed into them, butthey
would have strength, character and hab
its of thought and action of infir.itely
more value. H. GOODCELL.
Oakland.
IN ThjE NfIME Of THE DEAD.

express the situation and the sentiment
as these now lie:

wrone;

perslngr

City. Alpha is the first letter of tho
Greek alphabet, hence "the first. it is
pronounced alf-a, with the sound of : me
last a as in far; omega is the last letter
of the same alphabet, hence the Â»*Â«â 
It is pronounced o-me-ga, with me o
sounded as in o in move, c as is sounde
e in abiegate and a as in far.

S.. Martinez, Cal. Any person who ob
tains food or accommodation at an inn
or boarding-house without paying there
for with intent to defraud the proprietor
or manager thereof, or who obtains creaU
at an inn or boarding-house by the u^a
of any false pretense, or who, having ob
tained credit or accommodation at an ing
or boarding-house, absconds and surrep
titiously removes his Daggage there.Tonj
without paying for his food or Sccommo^
dation, is guilty of a misdemeanor.

EXEMPT FROM ATTACHMENTâ O.
S.. City. The law of the State of Califor
nia says of various matters that are ex
empt from attachment: "The earnings
of the judgment debtor for his personal
services rendered at any time within
thirty days next preceding the levy of ex
ecution or attachment, when it appears
by the debtors' affidavit, or otherwise,
that such earnings are necessary for tha
use of his family residing in this State,
supported in whole or in part by his la
bor, but where debts are incurred by any
such person, or his wife or family, fof
the common necessaries of life, oneÂ«
half of such earnings are. nevertheless,
subject to execution, garnishment or at
tachment to satisfy debts so incurred.

Song." about which another correspond
ent wrote: "Half a century or more ago
the Hutchinson family, Judson. Abba,
John and Asa, gave public concerts
throughout the New England States.

Down East.' of which the quotation
given was the fourth line of the first
verse. The song was sun? by John
Hutchinson. the comedian of the troupe,
who. with younger members of the fam
ily, gave concerts in San Francisco quite
a number of years ago. The song? -
by the quartet were published at a very
early date, and it is possible that they
can *be obtained from some of the old
established publishing houses of Boa
ton."

PRIZES FOR DAVY JOKES.
The armada Spain sent against England
had at least the merit of greatly outnum
bering the "English fleet- It is quite differ
ent with the quixotic armada which Spain
threatens to dispatch to far-off America
to attack a much larger fleet. The first
armada went to Davy Jones, and the sec
ond, in the nature of thins*, can hardly
fare better.â Globe-Democrat.EACTER MUSIC.
fy\ VSIC has come to be regarded
I I I as a part of Easter Sunday.
I Aside from the tender sentiment
\ I marking the anniversary, a sen
timent which it seems to carry
to the heart of the devout, it has a be
nign and chastening influence on every
hearer. "Within sacred walls, where the
nir is tivmukms with melody, there
seems no- place for the sordid or the
mean. Unconsciously the better im
pulses are stirred; the song is glorified
Into an invocation; the tone of the or
gan is an appeal. None go away save
with a sense of having been uplifted.
.Perhaps it is in part for the good it
nay do and in part for the happiness
It may give that music has been made
po important a feature of the Easter
service. This year the preparations are
even more elaborate and complete than
In former years, although the reputa
tion of San Francisco churches for
high class music has long been estab
lished. To-morrow the great cathedral
organs will respond to the touch of
masters, and anthems will rise in
churches all over the city. To all who
love melody there is in store a season
of elevating pleasure, and few there are
who do not love it.
Among the programmes arranged are
the following:

COSILY ERROR
IN THIS BILL
Refunding Bonds of Cities
and Towns May Be
Invalidated.
Mistake in a Measure Which
Passed California's
Senate.
Many Sections of the Statute Repealed
When the Act Became
a Uw.
Special Dispatch to The Call.
SACRAMENTO, April B.â A very in
teresting and probably a very serious
question has arisen in connection with
the passage of what is known as Sen
ate Bill No. 441, introduced in the last
passion of the Legislature by Senator
Bulla, passed and approved by the Gov
ernor on March 9, 1897. The act pro
vides for the refunding of indebtedness
of incorporated cities and towns by the
issuance of bonds therefor, and pro
vides for the payment thereof. The
general provisions of the act enable any
mon Council, Board of Trustees or
governing body of any city or
town, other than cities of the first
class, to fund cr refund any indebted
ness, by issuing bonds. After specify
ing certain restrictions and conditions
the act concludes with the following
sections:
Sec. 4. Chapter eighty-two of the Stat
utes of eighteen hundred and eighty
three, chapter forty-eight of the statutes
of eighteen hundred and ninety-three, and
chapter one hundred and seventy-six of
the statutes of eighteen hundred and
ninety-five, all being laws of the State o*
California In conflict herewith are hereby
repealed.
Sec. 6. This act shall take effect and be
in force immediately after its passage.
Herein lies the difficulty and is the
cause of much uneasiness on the part of
many cities and towns throughout the
State. It will be observed that chapter
48 of the statutes of 1893 is repealed, or
at least an attempt is m le to do so.
Now it is very evident from an exam
ination of that statute that such was
not the intention of the Legislature.
"Under chapter 47 are the sections which
were intendeu to be nullified. Some
mistake was evidently made by some
one and the question now ariaea, What
will be the effect?
Ir under this act of 1897 the sections
of chapter 48 are repealed there is no
law by which cities and towns of Cali
fornia containing more than 3000 and
less than 10.000 inhabitants can incur
an indebtedness for the construction of
â water works, sewers and all other pub
lic Improvements. If there are cities
and towns which have under that sec
tion Incurred sue' an indebtedness the
drew McCurda and Philip Murphy; bassos,
F. P. Scolllns and John J. Lernien; organist
and director, P. J. O' Sullivan.

stringed orchestra accompaniment. The vocal
soloists will be: Soprano, Mrs. Noonan: con
tralto. Miss Josephine Murphy, tenor, Signor
, Fernandous; basso. William Gordon. Before
the mass the orchestra, under the direction of
! Eugene E. Sohmidt, will render various selec

will give the "Reglna Coeli," by Glorza, solo
and chorus.

I validity of the obligation is certainly
questionable.
The mistake was discovered in the
Secretary of State's office to-day, and
1 there is no doubt that the discovery
will cause great uneasiness in many
! communities where public improve
i rnents have been contracted for under
j the law of 1893 or have been in contem
plation.
Private Secretary Shields of the Gov
ernor's office acknowledged that the
matter had not been brought before
him until to-day, but he had not as yet
made an examination nor had he dis
cussed it with the Governor. He was
inclined to the belief that Governor
Budd had not approved a bill which re
pealed another, not contemplated by
the Legislature or sanctioned by him.
Mr. Shields, in speaking off-hand, said
that he did not believe, in the first
place, that a former act of the Legisla
ture could be repealed in a subsequent
act by the mere designation of the
chapter. The act of 1897, in attempting
to repeal the act of 1893, referred to the
latter act by simply designating the
chapter. This, in Mr. Shields' opinion,
is not sufficient, as the chapter is not a
division contemplated by the constitu
tion or a division indicated by the Leg
islature.
The bills, when they reach the Gov
ernor, have been passed by the House
and Senate and signed by the Speaker
and President of the respective bodies.
The word "chapter" does not appear
i upon them until they have become laws
by the final approval of the Governor.
i As they are signed, the executive sec
i retaries designate them by chapters,
and in that shape they are bound. They
would be the law of the land just the
same were there no such a designation,
i and in fact such a division is merely a
; matter of convenience and forms no
vital requisite to the validity of any
statute. This being true, Mr. Shields
i claims that no act can be repealed by
a mere reference to the chapter.
If Mr. Shields is correct there has
been no repeal of the law of 1893, neith
er in respect to the issuance of bonds
! under chapter XLVII nor in respect to
the construction of water works and
other improvements under chapter
XLVIII. But as the first mentioned
act is by the construction of statutes
repealed by the subsequent conflict, it
will no doubt be claimed that the one
stands while the other falls. This po
sition may be correct, but it is to be
hoped that many statutes repealed in
the past have not been disposed of by
the mere reference to the chapter; be
cause if they have, under Mr. Shields 1
Interpretation they are still in force.
It is a matter which will no doubt
be determined properly, but in the
meantime many communities will be
disturbed. During this period of un
certainty the question will naturally
be asked, Who is to blame? A repre
sentative from the office of the Secre
tary of State and The Call correspond
ent examined ihe original bill of Mr.
Bulla, and found that there had been
no mistake in the enrollment. The bill
as drawn by Mr. Bulla repealed or at
tempted to repeal chapter XLVIII of
the statutes of 1893, when it should
have repealed or attempted to repeal
chapter XLVII of the statutes of 1893.
More Hydrants Asked For.
The Fire Commissioners have requested
the Supervisors to establish twenty-one
new fire hydrants in various parts of the
city. The recommendation includes five
new hydrants for one block on Sutter
street, as follows: Two on opposite
corners of Sutter and Powell; one In the
middle of the block, toward Mason, and
two more at the intersection of the latter
street.

GERMANY'S IRON
HAND IN CHINA
Gains a Concession for
Constructing Another
Railway.
Russia Asks That It Be Permit
ted to Lay a Line From
Port Arthur.
: Mint to Be Established at Vladivo
stok for the Coinage of
Silver.
Special Dispatch to The Call.
TACOMA, April B.â The Oriental liner
Olympia arrived here to-day, having
been detained at quarantine three days
on account of a smallpox patient put
ashore in Japan. The Olympia brings
advices up to March 18.
Besides the railway concessions al-
I ready procured from China, Germany
: has acquired another for the laying of
! a railway between Chinampho and
I Ichow.
The steamship Shukuga Maru foun
dered off the coast of Setana on March
9. The passengers are said to be safe.
A fire at Hiratsuka Machl destroyed
101 houses.
Minchhong-Mok, who granted to
Russia the lease of a coaling-station
on Deer Island, having become foreign
Minister of Korea, all the other Minis
ters of State have tendered their resig
nations. They have not, however, been
accepted, and the Ministers of the other
state departments have impeached
Minchhong-Mok. Mm will probably be
dismissed from office.
Russia has made a request that she
should be conceded the privilege of lay
ing the Liao Tung Railway, terminat
ing in Port Arthur.
The Â» British Government has ap
pointed Consul-General Jordan as Brit
ish Minister to Korea,
Kirn Hong Miuk has been appointed
Governor of Seoul.
Six hundred Formosa rebels attacked
a gendarmie barracks at Kimpori, but,
after a short engagement with troops
sent from Kelung, were dispersed.
During the trial trip of the new
Tenyu Maru the wind arose and the
vessel keeled over, filled and sank.
Eleven persons were drowned.
The Russian Government is preparing
for the establishment of a mint at
Vladivostok for the purpose of coining
silver rubles for the payment of wages
on the Manchurian railway.

The San Francisco Lying-in Hospital
will again open Its doors, at 913 Golden
Gate avenue, to-day. The place has been
thoroughly renovated and fitted and fur-

SOCIETY AT A PANSY TEA.
The Place of Meeting Was Profusely
Decorated With Wild Flowers.
The Ladies' Aid Society of Cooper
Memorial Congregational, Sunset dis
trict, gave a "Pansy Tea" last Thursday
at the residence of Mrs. W. H. Jones, 1348
Eleventh avenue, in aid of the church,
the first established south of Golden
Gate Park.
The spacious rooms were profusely dec
orated with wild flowers of every variety,
and a bountiful repast was served in the
dining room, the tables of which were
beautifully ornamented with pansies and
California poppies.
During the tea the guests were pleas
antly entertained by the following ladies
and gentlemen: Miss Lillian Rhodes,
recitation; Mr. Harrington and Mrs.
Clark, duet; Rev." Harry Perkes and Mrs.
Perkes sang several hymns and thgre
was singing by a quartet composed of
Mrs. Lillie, Miss Lou Ewald, Mr. Perkes
and Mr. Harrington. The following were
noticed as being present: Mrs. J. Rhodes,
Mrs. Rosenberg, Mrs. Harry Perkes, Mrs.
Nordhausen. Mrs. Hcnken, Mrs. Shu
bert, Mrs. Dr. Jones, Mrs. Cox, Mrs.
Charles Cushman, Mrs. R. Keller, Mrs.
Hallet, Mrs. A. Harrington, Mrs. Clark,
Mrs. G. Makinson, Mrs. Beck, Mrs. Mar
quart, Mrs. Hoffman, Mrs. Tompkins,
Mrs. E. Ewald, Mrs. W. H. Jones, Mrs.
W. H. Lillie, Miss Lillian Rhodes, Miss
Bessie Fidders. Miss Florence Harvey,
Miss May Meadowcraft, Miss Lou
Ewald, Miss Alice Perkes, Miss Freda
Marquart, Florence Harrington, Mabel
Jones, Rose Makinson, Mabel SalÃbury,
Maggie Foley, Grade Bell, Alma Ken
nedy, Irene Harrington, Hazel Bell,
Annie Steinberg, Rosie Dletz; Rev.
Harry Perkes, Messrs. W. M. Jones, Mr
Belzer, Richard Keller. J. Harris, Ed
ward Ewald, H. Steinberg, William
Schmidt, George Green, George Harvey,
Gus Fuchs, Will Makinson, Ralph Har
nish, William Bell, H. Jones, Louis Nord
hausen, George Makinson, L. Betz, David
Meadowcraft and Charles Cushman.
Town Talk.
This week's Issue of the favorite weekly
contains some especially interesting Saun
terer stories about people we know:
School Director "Waller, Jim Murphy, the
late Mrs. Emerlck. Lieutenant Milton, U.
S. N., Herr Stark. Grant Carpenter, a
wealthy Central American and his fian
cee, Henri Marteau and others. Clergy
men will be interested in the editorial dis
cussion upon certain late sermons preach
ed here upon the war subject. Miss Grace
Sherry is portraitized, and there is the
usual budget of stage and music, society
and club chat. â¢
MEMORIAL DAY.
Preliminary Steps Taken by the
Grand Army for Its Ob
servance.
At a meeting of Lincoln Post, G. A. R.,
held last Thursday night. Post Com
mander C. J. Handley was authorized to
call a meeting of post commanders in this
city for the purpose of taking the pre
liminary steps in the matter of properly
observing Memorial day this year.
It is probable that the post commander
will call the meeting for next Thursday
evening, when the matter will be fully
discussed.

DEGREE OF HONOR.
The Grand Lodge Closes Its Labors.
Election of Grand Officers.
The Grand Lodge of the Degree of
Honor closed its labors late yesterday af
ternoon after a two days' session.
In the forenoon the following grand offi
cers were elected for the current year:
Chief of honor, Mrs. E. F. Mayon of
Oakland; lady of honor, Viola Norman of
Monrovia; chief of ceremonies. Flora J.
Nay of Pasadena; usher, Cornelia Albln of
Fresno; inside watchman, Minnie F. Hol
lis of San Francisco; outside watchman,
Eva Booth of Los Angeles; recorder, Kate
M. Poland of San Francisco; receiver,
Maggie H. Ohea of San Francisco; medi-.
cal examiner, Dr. J. L. Mayon.
Mrs. Poland declined the nomination for
grand recorder, but the grand body re
fused to accept her declination and elect
ed her as a compliment to her efficiency.
A proposition to increase her salary was
declined by her for this year.
The following were chosen delegates to
the Superior Lodge of Honor: Mrs. Kate
M. Poland of Ivy Lodge and Mrs. Esther
Lovejoy and Mies M. Ohea of Minerva
Lodge.
The following committees were appoint
ed: â  Advisory to the grand chief of honor,
William Henry Barnes; lawsâ D. S. Hlrsh
berg, Mrs. G. Featherstone and Minnie
Bacon; finance â Eva Cogan, Nellie G.
Babcock and Loretta Donnelly.
The grand officers were installed by
Superior Chief of Honor Mrs. Steuart, as
sisted by William Vinter and William H.
Barnes.
During the session Chief of Ceremonies
"Viola Norman was apprised by telegraph
of the death of her father. The Grand
Lodge passed resolutions of sympathy.
Thanks were returned to the retiring
grand officers and to the lodges of this
city and Oakland, which on Thursday
night entertained the delegates, and then
the grand body adjourned.
Deputy Grand Master.
L. M. Manzer of Hercules Lodge has
been appointed by Grand Master Work
man Bahrs as deputy grand master work
man to fill the vacancy caused by the
election of Frank S. Poland, who for
twelve years held that office, to the office
of grand recorder. Mr. Manzer has been
connected with the order for a great
many years and, it Js stated, will very
faithfully discharge the duties of the
office.
The following are the new corporate di
rectors of the Ancient Order of United
Workmen: Wtlliam Vinter, George H.
Bahrs. J. W. Collins, J. H. Flint, Frank
S. Poland, Sam Booth, Dr. J. L. Mayon,
C. F. Curry. W. W. Hawkett, John
Hoesch and J. P. Jarman.
In the Divorce Court.
Cornelia Kohsaat has commenced suit
for divorce against Cecelio Kohsaat on
the ground of cruelty; Josephine A. Bean
from Joseph Bean, desertion, and Ger
trude Featherstone from Patrick Feath
erstone, cruelty.
Judge Hcbbard yesterday granted Jo
seph C. Freese a divorce from Helen L.
Freese on the ground of desertion.
Freese, who is a son of Public Adminis
trator Freose, was directed to pay $25 a
month alimony for the support of his di
vorced wife and child.
Judge Belcher has granted Frederick P.
Brown a divorce from Elizabeth E. Brown
on the ground of intemperance.
Mary Adams has secured a divorce from
John Adams on the ground of cruelty.
Ida Hoffman has secured a divorce from
Rudolph Hoffman on the ground of cru
elty. She has been granted also the right
to resume her maiden name, Ida Doan.
Arrested the Wrong Man.
R. J. McKnight, a groceryman at 1128
Folsom street, who was arrested Thurs
day night on complaint of R. S. Christie,
a "prophet," on suspicion of having
broken into Christie's house, has been re
leased by the police, as he proved that it
was a case of mistaken identity.
