Wants a State Convention.
SANTA CRUZ. April S.-A number of
prominent Democrats have a movement
on foot to have the next State Democratic
Convention meet in Santa Cruz. This city
s well adapted for the handling of a
large convention. X a
Trouble Over Assessments.
SAUSALITO, April S:-There is trouble
brewing over the street assessments In
Sausalito and a number of protests have
been filed with the Board of Town Trus
tees. Among the complainants are John
Schnell, G. W. Richards and H. Appleton.
The claim is made that the property-own
ers have been wrongly assessed, owing to
mistakes made by the engineer. The
claim is that the work on the streets is
not according to the contract; that it has
not been performed In a good and sub
stantial manner.
MAGUIRE AND "BILLY" MASON.
Washington Capitol.
Mason Is a sort of story-tellers' magnet.
Anecdotes cluster about him like iron
filings about a lodestone. One reason for
this is that he has always something to
say. There was that episode of mi with
the hotel clerk. Some men would nave
been embarassed after an encounter of
that kind, seeing their names in all the
papers which a clipping bureau can get
hold of. Mason wasn't; not a bit. He
met a newspaper man not long afterward,
and when the newspaper man asked him
now he came to get into that sort of
scrap he said tha Senator Cullom hud
been attracting so much attention lately :
| with his dog tight that it seemed about
tune for some other Senator to have a
chance at the public eye.
Lately he ..as been winding Congress
man Maguire of CaMxorola. up in his
! tangle of anecoote. Congressman Maguire '
: is snort, fat, curly-haired and looks rather
like .Mason. Sot long ago a man collared
him, metaphorically, of course, in the
corridor, and said:
I "Can 1 have a minute with you? There's
that matter, you -now, that you promised '
to help me about."
Maguire said he didn't remember any- â 
thing about it. :
,This is in reference to thatâ that i
position you were going to help me get,"
went on the stranger.
Maguire said that he did not think he
had ever met his interlocutor.
"Why," said the office-seeker, "you got j
a job for my brother-in-law and balled
out my nephew, andâ"
Then a light began to dawn on the
Calif ornlan, and he said: "I am Congress
man Maguire of California. You will find
Senator Mason at the end of the hall."
About three minutes after he met a !
newspaper man, to whom he told his tale, :
and said that as near as he could remem
ber that was the twenty-ninui man who
had mistaken him for Senator Mason and
wanted help of some kind or other. And
they all said that the Senator had prom-
I ised them help, and acted most confidently
I that he would give it to themâ noi con
fident in that insistent, bold, whistle-to
keep-your-courage-up kind of a way, but
confident as people are when they have a
good friend whom they know and on
j whom they can depend. But it strikes me
I that if there are any men whom Senator
! Ma-son really does not want to see he
! might use Maguire very nicely as an
understudy, and it also occurs to me that
before Maguire understood the state of
the case there may have been people who
thought that Mason, in spite of uls cher
ubic air of innocence and good will, was
a Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde character,
who was one thing one minute and an
other the next, and could not in the least
be trusted.
A LESSON IN FORESTRY.
Governor Atkinson of West Virginia, in
a late oracular after-dinner speech, de
clared that "the inexhaustible forests of
timber" in his State "could furnish
boards enough to fence in the universe."
We used to talk that way. in Pennsyl
| vania in our salad days, when we were
green in judgment, but we know better
now. With our barren uplands, our ;
dried-up streams and bleak and black
ened mountain sides we are contriving
how we may repair the senseless and
wasteful devastation of the past.â Phila- â 
delphia Record.
SMALL PREY FOR PRIVATEERS.
Excluding our coastwise trade with
America, the total number of American
vessels engaged In foreign trade that
cleared from our ports in 1897 was 739 sail-
Ing vessels and 458 steam. Durinsr the
same time 2171 foreign sailing vessels and
5511 foreign steamships sailed from Amer- ;
lean ports, carrying <S9 per cent of our im
mense foreign commerce. Even if the
dona should prove to be most alert as
privateersmen, there will be small pick- .
ings for them in the way of American
vessels engaged in foreign trade.âPitts
burg Post.
WESTWARD TREND OF TRAFFIC.
Westward the trend of traffic takes its
way. The Pacific Coast railroads reported
an increase of 33 per cent in earnings for
the month of February. The Alaskan
gold craze helps the Pacific roads might
ily; but there is fast developing the solid
foundation of mighty States on the Pa
cific Coast compared with the volume of
whose industrial production the gold of
the Yukon region will be insignificant.â

more than l l^ inches in a year.
A FARMER'S MISHAP.
JUMPS FROM HIS WAGON AND IS
BADLY INJURED.
Injuries Which Gilbert Updegraff Sus
tainedâMuch Suffering Endured.
How He Obtained Relief.
From the Democrat, Goshen, Ind.
Gilbert UpdeÃraff, a prosperous farmer
living near Goshen. Ind.. In lumping from
his wagon on to a board, a few days ago,
met with a serious accident.
It was feared at first that this accident
was aggravated by rheumatism, which
ailment Mr. Updegraff was troubled with
some time ago in an unusually severe
form. In speaking of it he says:
"About two years ago I was stricken
with rheumatism, and for a year was se
verely troubled with it. It came on me
suddenly during the winter, I don't know
what caused it, unless it was exposure,
about the farm.
"It was the old fashioned rheumatism
and began in my lower limbs, gradually ''.
working up until my arms, hands and
fingers became affected. My body ached ;
all over, especially my limbs, which were
swollen and these by the following spring
Were almost entirely useless. I had to '
hire all my work done that spring and
summer, but did a little work In har
vest time.
"I must have done too much, for soon
after that I was confineu to my bed for
some time. I had the famllv doctor, but
he didn't do me any good. He finally said
he could not help me and advised "me to
try the baths, but I couldn't afford the
expense. Neither could I afford to be an
invalid all my life. Inquiries were made
at the drug store for something that
would be helpful in my case.
"The druggist recommended several i
things, and I tried some of them but '
was not benefited until I used Dr "Wil
tUttas' Pink Pills for Pale People, i gave !
this remedy a fair trial, as I did the ;
others, and soon discovered that it was
different from anytning I had tried
"I found that this was a medicine that '
did what was claimed for it. and when I
had taken about a dozen doses of the Dills
I found that they were helping me I
continued taking tnem. and I am glad to
day that I did. Why that medicine actu
ally cured me and I didn't take niore than
six or seven boxes either.
"It was In January. 1887, that I began
taking the medicine, and I was complete
ly cured by the first of March I beean
early in the spring to do my work arid I
kept it up all summer, not missing a day
I have never had any rheumatic trouble
with ray limbs from that day to this "
"Arid are you positive that it was Dr
Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People that
cured you?" asked the reporter.
"Positive, why of course I am. Nothing
else did it. I did not take any other med
icine at the time, and I was never better
until I began taking Dr. Williams' Pink
Pills for Pale People. I have taken noth- j
Ing else since, and of course they are
what did the work." Mrs. T'pdegraff i
agreed with her husband that "he was i
cured of a very severe case of rheuma- !
tism by these pills."
What better proof could a person want
than the above facts? This plainly shows ;
that Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale â 
People are unrivaled as a tonic for the !
blood. The secret of perfect health '
strength and beauty is pure blood, and I
impure blood is the foundation of most j
diseases.

dies which acts on the impure and im
poverished blood. Imparting those ele
ments that purify, vitalize and enrich It. !

eign climes. These marvelous health re- !

The year 1898 comprises the latter
Dirt of the 122 d and the beginning of
the 123 d year of the independence of the
United States of America. It corre
fcI The yS t'wii of the Julian period
The year 7406-7407 of the Byzantine
era the year 7407 beginning September 1
The year 5655-5659 of the Jewish era,*
the year 5659 beginning at sunset on'
SS TT P ne m ye e ar 2651 since the foundation of
Rome, according to Varro.
The year 2645 since the beginning of
the era of Nabonassar, which has been
assigned to Wednesday, the ~6Ui of
February, of the 396, th year of the
Julian period: corresponding. In the
notation of chronologies, to the 74<th
and in the notation of astronomers to
the 746 th year before the birth of Christ.
The year 2674 of the Olympiads -r
the second year of the 669 th Olympiad
beginning in July, if we fix the er,i of
che Olympiads at 773% B. C.
The year 2210 of the Grecian era, or
the era of the Seleucidae.
The year 1614 of the era of Diocletian
The year 2553 of the Japanese era ana
the thirty-liret year of the period en
titled Meiji.

medan era, or the era of the. Hegira,
the year 1316 beginning May 22.

TO GET AT
THE TRUTH
The Water Compa
nies' Hand in Local
Politics.
Inspector Smith Does Not
Testify as He
Swore.
Ex-Mayor Chapman Kills the
Coffin Case at the
Start.
FARCE IN A LAW COURT.
No Desire Now to Use "the People"
In the Great Corporation
Contest.
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway. April 8.
"I purpose to show that the
Board of Health of the city of
Oakland, and certain officers of
the present city government,
owe their appointment to the ac
tive influence of the Oakland
Water Company, and that these
proceedings were instituted
against Coffin by this water
company; that for a long time
prior to and after the present
Board of Health was appoint
ed the Oakland Water Company
was engaged in slandering the
water of the Contra Costa Com
pany, and that this suit is sim
ply a put-up job of the company
to hoodwink the people. I am
showing- the animus in this suit.
I am trying to show that the
Board of Health is simply the
tool of the Dingee people and
that Inspector Smith is the ex
ecutive officer of the Board of
Health. I don't say that the
water companies are hostile
now. Oh. no, they are two souls
Utterly harmonious; but I pur
pose to show that at the time
this complaint was filed there
was deadly hostility existing be
tween the two watercompanies."
Such was the opening statement of
Mr. Chapman's "purposes" this morn
ing, but the prosecution did not pur
pose that Mr. Chapman should carry
out such a vigorous programme, and
therefore the defendant was dismissed.
The trial of the Coffin case to-day
produced some peculiar testimony and
ended In a farcical manner. Harry
Melvtn, who represented the District
Attorney's office on behalf of the people,
had the thankless task of conducting a
prosecution in which the prosecutors
did not care to prosecute.
The main witness for the people was
Banltary Inspector Smith, and had he
been for the defense he could not have
made a better witness. Mr. Smith stated j
that in the complaint as filed in court
were allegations that he had never
â worn to; that the complaint was inter
lined after he had signeu it, and that j
had he seen it or had it been read to
him in the condition in which it was
filed he would never have sworn to it.
Ex -Mayor Chapman, who appeared j
for Coffin, turned Mr. Smith into a most !
excellent witness for the defendant,
and the prosecution was at the very
outset shown to have no case, llad the i
suit been tried at the time it was filed
in the fall of last year, when the rival
water companies were fighting for pat
ronage, it would have provoked a very
warm contest. Now the companies hay- :
Ing shaken hands there is no longer
any desire to prove on either side that j
the water of the other company is full ,
if microbes and pollution and conse
quently the Sanitary Inspector who ;
ewes his appointment to the Board of ,
Health which owes its appointment to
Mayor Thomas, who is commonly sup- j
posed to have been helped in his elec- I
tion by the water companies, certainly i
has no object in testifying contrary to \
the wishes of those who keep him in of
flee.
It was seen at the beginning that the
case was to be allowed practically to
fall through, as only J. H. T. Watkin
scm of the Contra Costa Water Com
pany, of all the prominent witnesses
summoned, put in an appearance. He
did not hurt the case one way or the
other, his testimony being mostly
stricken out after he had left the
stand. It was the intention of Mr.
Chapman to have produced evidence to
show that Attorney Herrin of the
Water Front Company came over here
last spring, consulted with political
managers and water company mana
gers as to how Oakland should be gov
erned during the coming administra
tion, but, owing to the evident desire
not to hurt anybody, his plans were
thwarted, and after the prosecution
had put in its powerful side of the case
it was so eminently favorable to the
defendant that he was dismissed.
Mr. Coffin was charged with willfully
and all other kinds of ways polluting
n. public water supply against all kinds
"f public health, peace, dignity and
Mmilar civilrights. The evidence showed
that he had not polluted the wat
ers, that there was no water to pollute;
that if there had been any water it j
was not supplied to the people of the
city of Oakland, although it might have
got into the pipes in some manner, and
It was also pro-ved that Mr. Coffin was
rot the lessee of the premises, and that
If a nuisance consisting of the high
misdemeanor charged had been main
tained, it was maintained by John
Avala, who is a tenant of Coffin's, and ;
that therefore the allegations in the
complaint did not in any way concern
thÂ» man who had been arrested and
prosecuted.
Such is the fate of the case which
was begun by one of the water com
panies and which both of them were
anxious to quash when it came to trial.
Their anxiety was quickly relieved.
Evening Classes Commencement.
OAKLAND. April B.â The annual com
mencement exercises of the evening edu
cational department of the Young Men's
Christian Association will be held In the
Auditorium of their building on Tuesday
evening next. The teachers and students
will have a social gathering afterward in
the dining-rooms. The classes in electric
ity, bookkeeping and mechanical drawing
nave passed the International examina
tions, and will receive the certificates is
sued by that body.

A YOUNG WIFE FREE.
Mrs. G. R. R. Ainsworth Is
Awarded Her Piano and Also
a Divorce.
OAKLAND, April S.â Captain George
R. R. Ainsworth was divorced to-day
from his girl-wife, and there will be no
sensational trial. The findings in the ea*e.
signed by Judge Hall, were filed this af
ternoon, and were very brief. They
merely stated that it was true that the
defendant married Ida Murphy, that there
were no children, that the charges of ex
treme cruelty were sustained, and touna
that judgment should be entered on be
half of the fair young plaintiff.
The final lindinp. therefore, gives to
Miss Ida Murphyâfor she is permitted to
resume her maiden nameâ the .piano she
so greatly craves, and nothing is said
about alimony or distribution of property.
RESCUED FROM HER MOTHER.
Little Kuth Myer Saved by Mrs.
Prescott of the Children's
Society.
OAKLAND. April S.-Little Ruth
Myer was taken from a house in Berke
ley last night by Mrs. Prescott of the
Children's Society. The child is but 2V4
years old. r.nd her unnatural mother has
left her all alone.
Lillian Myer has been watched by the
police for several weeks, and after as
surances were found that she was not a
fit person to have her child Mrs. Pres
cott \vÂ»s notified and took away the
child at night.
The young mother returned after mid
night and found her child gone. She
hunted vp Mrs. Prescott in the early
hours of this morninj? and tried to make
a scone, but when she discovered that
her method of living was known, she con
sent, d to her child going to the Maria
Kip Orphanage.
A "JOKER" MAY
MAR THE PETITION
Attorney Davis Suspects a Re- i
quest of the C. C. Brock
Company.
On Its Face the Document Asks for a
Change In the Lines of the
Harbor.
OAKLAND, April S.â Following Is the
petition to change the pier-head lines of
the harbor that has been tiled by the C.
C. Brock Company with the Government
engineers:
The undersigned corporation, the C. C. Brock
Company, is a co-owner in sixteen vessels en
gaged in the bay and coastwise trade In and
around San Francisco, C'al.
We are advised that the Government engi
neers who established and laid out the exist
ing pierhead lines in Oakland, Oal., harbor,
inasmuch as the entire water front was at the
time of such survey and location claimed by a
private corporation, bo adjusted such pierhead
lines as not t.j trespass upon private property
for the purpose of avoiding condemnation pro
ceedings and like expenditures.
That since said lines were established, to-wit:
within the past ninety days, a decision has
been rendered by the Supreme Court of this
State which finally settles and determines the
holding of said corporation claimant, which
said decision leaves outside of said pierhead
lines and between them and the property of
said corporation a wide strip of water which
is declared to be in public ownership.
That said water front corporation and other
riparian owner* have the right, however, sub
ject of course to Federal supervision, to con
struct wharves out to said flrst established
pierhead lines.
That the corporation being: the riparian own
er In said harbor is about t.> subdivide and
sell Us water front holdings in said harbor,
which will invite and result in the construction
of a great number of wharves and permanent
improvements out to said pierhead lines and
on both yidet* of said harbor.
That the construction of *uch wharves will
greatly narrow said harbor and render it a
strip of water of varying width but averaging
to some 800 feet only.
That such narrowing will greatly increase the
cost of shipping from said harbor, inasmuch as
it will make towing in and out of said harbor
a necessity, and will prevent ships anchoring
in the stream, so Increasing dock charges.
That further, the selling and Improving of
said water front will largely increase the
commerce of said port, while it will diminish
the facilities for conducting such commerce,
and that, too, in localities most used by com
merce.
The imaginary lines now laid down in said
harbor offer no obstruction to commerce, and
litigation having heretofore suspended the con
struction of wharves, the full width of the
estuary has been and is to-day as much used
by commerce as though formally dedicated
thereto, which we, your petitioners, seek to
perpetuate and secure before extensive Im
provements will render the same less easy,
and perhaps impossible, to effect.
Your petitioners therefore pray that said
harbor lines may be widened so as to Include
within the established pierhead lines all pub
lic lands or waters therein, and so prevent the
construction of wharves beyond the line of
private ownership and forever preserve to com
merce the full width of said harbor.
And your petitioners will ever pray.
THE C. C. BROCK CO..
By T. J. Shannon, Secretary.
W. R. Davis of counsel for the city in
the water-front suits thinks there is
something 1 underlying this petition and
will attend the meeting of the 18th inst.,
at which it will be considered.
TO .twAISE A REGIMENT.
An Unknown Man of Wealth Who
Will Equip a Thousand Mount
ed Infar try.
ALAMEDA, April B.â At the meeting of
Company G last evening the announce
ment was made by a member that a
wealthy gentleman o. San Francisco, who
desired to keep his name a secret for the
present, had derided to raise a regiment
of a thousand men, whicli he proposed to
arm and equip as mounted infantry at his
own expense. He has gone Kast to obtain
permission from the Government authori
ties at Washington to do this, and as
soon as he has obtained the required au
thority he will proceed at once with the
enlistment of men.
He has expressed a desire to raise one
company in Alamoda, and from the recep
!.on accorded the proposition last evening
it promises to be an easy task to accom
plish. The members of Company G of this
city are enthusiastic and are ready to
answer the call at any time to take the
field against the Spaniards.

ALAMEDA, April B.â The Young Men's
Club of the Presbyterian church of this

fitted up and other accommodations for

running the sharp point of a pencil into
a finger some urne ago.

church will leave for the East and Eu
rope on Tuesday next and will reutrn in

THE SAX FRANCISCO CALL, SATURDAY, APRIL 9, 1898.
ALL ANXIOUS
FOR HARMONY
Young Men Republicans
Seem Unable to
Secure It.
Much Regret Over the Little
Unpleasantness at the
Hall.
Leaders Declare That the Affair Is
Not Possessed of Any Official
Significance.
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway, April 8.
Five hundred young men, Republi
cans, are walking around to-day talk
ing on the street corners and in public
places and trying to discover what is
meant by "harmonizing."
There is good reason for the discus
sion. Last night there were two Re
publican Leagues. One waa led by
President Frank Bilger, the other by
President Pulcifer. To-day there are
all the way from four to six clubs,
Murray Laidlaw having developed into
a leader, while there are other fac
tions under disputed leaderships. For
a year the young men Republicans
have been misunderstanding each
other. A week ago one branch, consist
ing of about 350 members, organized
and elected Mr. Bilger. Last night
Harry Pulcifer, who was president of
an original Republican League, sent
out invitations to all the members of
all the young men's Republican leagues
to attend his meeting at Fraternal
Hall.
The response to his invitations over
came by about 350 his mo-si sanguine
expectations. The word was passed {
around among the members of the Bil- ;
ger League to turn out in force, and
they did so.
Mr. Pulcifer called the meeting to
order, but had no sooner done so than
there was some kind of a misunder
standing between him and Murray Laid
law, each of them having same sup
port. The 350 opponents to the Pulcifer
League had all gone there in the inter
ests of harmony.
The meeting had no sooner com
menced than the harmony began to
work. A party from the audience
jumped up on the platform and there
was a mix-up. So-me heavy blows were
struck, Bert Swan figuring in one little
contest, while some innocent members
ran their noses against fists without
any intention of doing so on their part.
Mr. Cal Ewing made an attempt to
speak in favor of harmony, but just
A MEMORIAL TO BISHOP KJP-
Window for t^e Chancel of the Good Samaritan
Mission.
The handsome chapel of the Cathedral Mission of the Good Samaritan at
Second and Folsom Btreets is to be further adorned by the addition of a
very handsome stained-glass window for the chancel, which will be un
veiled on EaÃter morning, April 10. Through the thoughtful kindness and
liberality of Mrs. Colonel Baldwin of New Haven, Conn., a relative of the
Rev. W. I. Kip Jr., who is minister in charge of the mission, this fine
work of art has been provided. Appropriately the window will be a me
morial of the first Episcopal Bishop of California. The window is in every
way worthy of the distinguished prelate whom it commemorates and iv
beauty of color and design will be surpassed by but few other specimens
of the art to be found anywhere. The subject of the illumination is Christ
healing the sick and is an almost perfect copy of Hoffmann's famous pic
ture. The unveiling of the window on Easter morning will be marked with
much ceremony. The execution of the window was intrusted to the United
Glass Works.
at this juncture somebody received a
blow on the lace that knocked him
backward and there was a crash, fol
lowed by the hissing of escaping gas.
One of the chandeliers in the hall had
been knocked down and confusion fol
lowed. Finally J. W. Stetson of the
opposition tried to make a speech, but
while he was doing so policemen at
tracted by the rioting went into the
hall and compelled the harmonizers to
disband.
Much regret is expressed to-day over
the event, and it is acknowledged on
all hands that it would have been bet
ter for the Bilger League, having al
ready claimed to be the genuine Young
Men's Republican League, to have
ignored Mr. Pulcifer's meeting alto
gether. As it is, both sides have suf
fered. The Bilger League has suf
fered in prestige, while the Pulcifer
League has been proved to be greatly
in the minority. The officers of the
Bilger League, including A. H. Breed,
its president, regret the incident and
declare that had not Mr. Pulcifer sent
out his invitations the members would
not have attended.
The matter to-day is being discussed
with more interest even than the Span
ish complications, and it is prognosti
cated that a few individuals who took
a prominent part would have better
for their political interests remained
away.
OAKLAND WINS THE DEBATE.
Second Forensic Contest Between the
Berkeley and Oakland High.
Schools.
BERKELEY, April B.â The Oakland
High School won the second inter-high
school debate between Oakland and
Berkeley at Shattuck Hall, Berkeley, to
night. The question for debate was, "Re
solved, That the Steam Railroads of the
United States Should Be Owned and Op
erated by the United States." The
Berkeley Hiph School, which had the af
firmative, was represented by Harry
Johnson, W. A. E. Woods and Leon Mar
tin. For the negative were the Oakland
High School debatersâ Winfield H. Dorn,
Louis A. Roseberry and Ben \>. Reed.
Leo H. Dungun, president of the Berke
ley High School Forum, made the opening
address. Hay McCargar, president of the
Oakland High School Senior Debating
Society, responded. The judges of the de
bate were Professor Thomas R. Bacon of
the University of California, Judge S. P.
Hall of Oakland and Horace G. Platt of
San Francisco. The committee of arrange
ments in charge of the debate consisted
of the following: Loring I. Barker, l^ouis
Cling, Harry A. Jonnson, Edward A.
Spencer, Clii'ton Knoll and "Wintleld M.
Dorn.
Garbage Crematory to Move.
OAKLAND, April B.â Steps have been
taken to remove the plant of the Oak
land Garbage Crematory from its present
location at Peralta and Twenty-eighth
Btreets. The 'orporation proposes to con
tinue its fight to secure the exclusive
contract to dispose of the city's garbage.
It recently paid the $300 due the city as
the second installment on the bonus of
fered. It proposes to try to secure a
franchise in Alameda and in that event
it will locate the plant on the marsh
between the two cities.
Harbor Dredging to Begin.
OAKLAND, April B.â Actual work upon
the dredgitig of the Oakland harbor below
Webster-streel bridge, for which a con
tract amounting to $101,500 has just been
let, will not begin for four weeks yet.
The dredjr^r which is to do the work is
at present in Vallejo on a Government
job and will nut leave it until finished
or the other one Is repaired sufficiently
to replace it.
THRASHED HIS
WIFE'S LOVER
Rajas Found Aston in His
House Christmas
Day.
Quickly Acqu.tted of Battery
He Will Soon Get a
Divorce.
The Visitor Was Caught Hugging
and Kissing the De:endant's
Wife.
Oakland Office San Francisco Call,
908 Broadway, April 8.
Many of the leading Portuguese res
idents at Alvarado were in Judge Hall's
courtroom to-day to hear and testify
in the divorce case brought by Guada
lupe Ilajas against his wife, Refugio A.
Rajas. The parties to the suit are
well known in the upper part of the
county and their trouble has aroused
great interest.
Rajas blames his neighbor, Philip
Aston, for breaking up his family and
in his story he tells of finding Aston in
I his home and of giving him a severe
\ thrashing. This occurred on Christ
j mas day. Rajas returned home and
! saw Aston kiss his wife. This was
' more than his patience could stand, so
| he used his fists on his wife's lover.
! Aston was foolish enough to have Ra
; jas arrested for battery and the trial, a
| few weeks ago, created quite a sensa
i tion in Judge Richmond's courtroom.
Rajas demanded a jury trial and a
1 jury of the most wealthy citizens was
impaneled, representing over a million
dollars.
Kajas took the stand in his own be
half, admitted the truth of the charge
and told his story to the jury. He said
he went home on Christmas day and
found Aston making love to his wife.
He had previously given Aston warn
ing to keep away, but the warning had
been disobeyed. Rajas said that he
did not feel inclined to kill Aston, so
he merely thrashed and gave him a
black eye. The jury promptly acquitted
him on the charge of battery and the
story was told in the Superior Court
to-day, as showing the standing of Mrs!
Rajas in the vicinity of his home.
The plaintiff had made out his case,
but as there are three daughters of
Mrs. Rajas by a former husband, it
was decided in their interest to mod
ify the allegations, and the complaint
when amended will be confined to
cruelty and neglect. Rajas will be
granted his divorce after his attorney,
ex-Judge E. M. Gibson, has amended
the complaint.
BASKET-BALL GIRLS.
They Are Beady for the Interstate
Fray This Afternoon.
BERKELEY, April B.â Half of Reno and
the whole of the University of Nevada
were at the Reno depot last night to shout
for the basket-ball team and to wish it
success. Passengers trying to sleep in the
Pullmans were roused when they reached
Nevada's metropolis by the free, loyal,
full-lunged Nevada boys' repeated good
by to the sagebrush co-eds.
Wah! Hoo! Wah!
Zip. Boop! Ah.
Rah! Rah! Rah!
Nevada!
At Sixteenth street, Oakland, the sage
brush athletes were met by Mrs. Magee,
who Is to referee Saturday's game, and a
committee of two Berkeley co-eds. The
whole party, chaperoned by Mrs. .T. N.
Evans, wife of the president of the Board
of Regents of Nevada's university, and
Miss Bardenwerper, and accompanied by
wee, golden-haired, gray-eyed , Rowena
Evans, the Nevadans' mascot, proceeded
to the Cliff House, where luncheon was
served and all the sights > were enjoyed.
They will return to Reno Sunday evening.
'Miss- Mayme Merrit of Stanford has
consented to act as umpire of the great
game.
The Nevada team does not expect to
defeat the clever Berkeley girls.
"We are a new team," said pretty Cap
tain Louise Ward. "We've had only three
weeks' -practice, and we're particularly
unfortunate just now, because our best
player, Nell Lewers, is ill and had to be
left at home. Miss Mclntyre has kindly
jumped into the breach, and will play
right center. But she is out of practice,
having played only three times within the
past year. . Three of the team are just
recovering . from the grip. So you see
we're not in the best condition. Still, we
have excellent individual players, thougn
our team work isn't ail we'd wish it, to De,
and we intend to play as hard and as well
as we can. If we're beaten, our defeat
will teach us something, for Nevada Uni
versity girls haven't had an opportunity
to, see a game of basket-ball, much less
to take part in one against a trained
team."
The Berkeley co-eds are in excellent
training, and will play a very interesting
game. Should they succeed in carrying
oft the basket-ball honors, as is probable,
there will not be the slightest ill-feeling
between the two teams of fair athletes,
for the generous hospitality 01 Berkeley
has quite won the hearts of the Nevada
girls.
EDITOR HOPPER WROTH.
Charges Stanford Athletic Authori
ties With Using Methods Un
sportsmanlike and Dishonest.
BERKELEY, April 8. â Editor James
Hopper of the University Occident in to
day's issue of the college weekly charges
the athletic authorities at Stanford with
acting the part of wily diplomats and re
sorting to methods "unsportsmanlike, pet
ty, mean, dishonest and unworthy of a
great university." Hopper bases his
charges upon the refusal of the Stanford
tennis authorities to meet California's
representatives to arrange for an inter
collegiate tournament, and the determina
tion of Stanford's track athletic repre
sentative to protest Ray Carroll, one of
California's athletes, after announcing
that no such action would be pursued.
Editor Hopper's caustic denunciation of
Stanford's methods is in part as follows:
It seems, from all evidences, that Stan
ford athletics are directed by men who
play the wily diplomats. They delight in
puerile and mean ntue maneuvers, affect
deep distrust of our most natural actions,
counterplot darkly against the atrocious
schemes of their own imaginations. They
lose athletic agreements: they refuse to
ratify clauses of intercollegiate agree
ments proposed v tneir own representa
tives; they seek to evade the tennis tour
nament, or, at least, to delay it to tne
period of our exes. They seek success in
a tortuous and ridiculous Machiavellism
which is exasperating. This deplorable
tendency is evidenced in the method by
which they seek to deprive us of one of
our best athletes. Stanford University is
going to protest Ray Carroll at the next
P. A. A. meeting. This threat is not of
a nature to affright us into hysterics. The
charges against Carroll are ridiculous.
Ray Carroll acts as monitor at the Deaf
and Dumb Asylum. Among his multiple
duties is the one of leading the children
in the callsthenic exercises. It is this
heinous offense which is unbearable to
Stanford athletic Puritans and the cause
of the crusading wrath.
Now that the field day is imminent;
now that there is no time for investigat
ing the matter thoroughly, representa
tives of Stanford University suddenly
change their mind %nd announce their in
tention of protesting Carroll. Is this not
an answer to our question? Does not this
discover the purpose of Stanford men in
The fao-simile ytf L//^*,*?^ *â¢ Oli ever 7 "wrapper
signature of C#m//z7<CUcÂ£<AZ of CASTOEIA.
protesting Carroll? It certainly seems so.
It looks like a de.iberate attempt to be
smirch the brilliance of our victory by
false accusations, by insidious calumny;
it looks like an endeavor to halo the rÂ«Â«
diance of our success with false haze of
doubt and uncertainty. It is an attempt
to make our hard-won conquest unsatis
factory and questionable. It is a proceed
ing unsportsmanlike, petty, mean and dis
honest, unworthy of a great university.
READY 'xO MEET STANFORD.
Berkeley Baseball Players Are Given
a Bally by Student Enthusisasts.
BERKELEY, April B.â The first of the
series of three baseball games between
the University of California and Stanford
University will take place at Recreation
Park, Eighth and Harrison streets, San
Francisco, to-morrow afternoon at 3
o'clock. The remaining two games of the
series will be played on the 16th and 30th
inst., respectively.
The Berkeley students gathered on the
campus this morning to give the team a
rally before the game. Brief remarks
were made by the members of the team,
Professor Syle and a number of prominent
students. Yells and cheers were prac
ticed for use in the big game to-morrow.
The California nine practiced yesterday
and to-day at Recreation Park, where the
game will be played. The Varsity, as it
will line up to-morrow, is as follows:
Catcher, Mem; pitcher, Kaarsburg; first
base. Bride; second base, McLaren; third
base, Baer; shortstop. McCabe; left held,
Chesebrough; center field, Hoag (captain);
right field, Collins.
Berkeley News Notes.
BERKELEY, April B.â F. W. Kerns of
Hollister. a freshman student in the col
lege of mechanics, has been awarded the
Levi Strauss scholarships made vacant by
Che resignation of Saul Epstein '00.
The freshmen have decided to hold their
Bourdon burial celebration on the univer
sity campus on Monday evening, April 20.
Professor Edmund J. James of the Uni
versity of Chicago, formerly of the Uni
versity of Pennsylvania and president of
the American Academy of Political and
Social Science, has accepted the invita
tion extended by President Kellogg on
behalf of the regents to deliver the com
mencement address to the graduating
class on May 18.
Captain R. P. Thomas of Berkeley has
applied to Secretary of War Alger for
permission to recruit soldiers In Alameda
County for war with Spain.
The trustees of the South Berkeley
Presbyterian Church have purchased the
lot on the southwest corner of Lorin and
Russell streets for the erection of a new
church edifice.
Professor E. H. Griggs of Stanford
University will lecture at Stiles' Hall on
Sunday evening, under the auspices of
the Berkeley Unitarian Society, on "The
Ethics of Hamlet."
The annual election of directors of the
Students' Co-operative Society at the
university to-day resulted in the election
of the following board of directors: Pro
fessor M. W. Haskell, Professor C. C.
Plehn, E. T. Clark, W. W. Mem and E.
R. Leach.
".Prosecution to Rest.
OAKLAND, April S.â The Martin $50,000
damage case was to-day continued until
Tuesday, when it is expected that the
plaintiff will finish his testimony and rest
the case. The usual motion for a non
suit will then follow, but those who have
followed the testimony declare that this
will not be granted, as too good a case
has been made out. Dr. W. S. Thorne,
president of St. Mary's Hospital of San
Francisco, was a good witness to-day,
and will complete his testimony Tuesday.
Dr. Young of Irvington. who attended the
injured man at first after the accident,
will be the last witness. He is at the
deathbed of his sister in Oakdale or tho
case would have gone on to-morrow.
Oakland News Items.
OAKLAND, April B.â Johanna Christen
sen was sent to Stockton to-night at the
request of her brother, for insanity.
Judge Hall granted a divorce this after
noon in the Rajos case on the petition of
the husband.
The report that the Associated Charities
would close their woodyard does them a
great Injustice, as it is without founda
tion. They never close for any reason,
but a cprtain local evening paper makes
such a statement regularly.
L. C. Clinton- of Glenn County has filed
a suit for $2500 damages against John
Gale of 1319 Broadway. The case has been
transferred to this county for trial.
Ebell Annual Election.
OAKLAND, April s.â The annual meet
ing and election of the Ebell Club w"ru*
held to-day. Out of the 4MÂ» members 171
attended the polls. The following board
of nine directors was elected: Mrs. Bun
nell, Mrs. A. W. Bishop. Mrs. I. Cockroft,
Mrs. Lullds, Mrs. Prentiss Selby, Miss
Jennie Huff. Mrs. E. W. Owen. Mrs. H.
B. Pinney. Mrs. Bunnell will be re-elected
president.
Swindlers in Australia.
ALAMEDA, April B.â Word ha.Â« been re
ceived that a couple of confidence opera
tors who swindled a good many Alameda
people a couple of years ago have been at
their old tricks in Australia, and have
just reaped a harvest. Augustus Howard
wa.s the name of tne chief of the couple,
and he was the one who did most of the
illicit scheming. He had a patent gas
machine, with which and a- lot of bogus
diamonds he swindled several people in
this city and in San Francisco. They fin
ally made a good haul arr' left for Aus
tralia. Under the names of Lee and h.i
liott they have now swindle a number of
people in Sydney out of s<^*ne $20,000 with
the same bogus gas machine they oper
ated here.
SOCIETY EVENTS.
The wedding of Miss Blanche Goggin
and Clyde C. "Westover (with the firm
of Hirschman & Co.) took place on April
2, at the residence of the bride, before the
relatives and a few Intimate friends, Rev.
E. J. Lion officiating. The bridal party
entering the beautifully decorated
parlors was preceded by Miss Maude and
Master Clyde Curley, tne niece and
nephew of the br'de, followed by the maid
of honor. Miss May Miles. The bride en
tered last, on the arm of her brother.
After the ceremony congratulations
were showered on the young couple, after
w-.ch a wedding breakfast was served
at tete a tete tables. The bride's dress
was white organdie over satin, the brides
maid being also in white, over pink. Tne
happy couple were the recipients of many
beautiful gifts. Â±ar. and Mrs. Westover
have left for San Jose, where the honey
moon will be spent.
Mrs. D. Gorman and her daughter, Miss
X F. Gorman, left San Francisco April
1. They will go to Los Angeles, San Diego
and Mexico, returning in three months.
Mrs James O'Brien has gone to Sausa
lito to remain until they return.
Mr. and Mrs. S. Kahn (nee Clayburgh)
have returned from their southern trip,
and have left for an extended European
The Mystics will five an Easter party
next Tuesday evening at Native Sons'
Captain and Mrs. Charles Minor Goodall
have returned from their wedding trip,
and are at home at 150 Lake street, Oak-
Coionel J. C. Currier and family are at
San Mateo for the summer. Mrs. cur
rier's mother and sister, Mrs. Smith, and
Miss Greenwood Smith, who are spending
the winter on tais coast, are with them.
I^r. and Mrs. Homer Craig have sold
their Lake-street home, across the bay,
and w... hereafter pass the winters in
San Francisco and the summers in Los
Gatos.
Miss Ethel Pomeroy, who has beÂ«n
spending the winter at the Occidental
Hotel, is now the guest of Mr. and Mrs.
W. V. "Witcher. .
The wedding of Henry Mltau and Miss
Alice Taussig will take place at the home
of the bride's mother, 2127 California
street, on Sunday, the 17th inst. It wnl
tee a quiet family affair.
Huntington's Reply.
At a recent meeting of the Board of
Supervisors, a resolution was passed
asking the Market-street Railroad Com
pany if it would pave that portion of
Market street with bitumen it is required
by law to keep in repair, to conform to
the rest of the street where it is proposed
to lay the new pavement. Yesterday
Clerk Russell received a brief reply
signed by H. E. Huntington, stating that
the directors had held their annual meet
ing just before the Supervisors' request
had been received, but that he would be
willing to meet any representative of the
board it might designate and talk the
matter over.
PRINTERS CLAIM
AN ADVANTAGE
One More Offics Reported to
Have Acceded to Their
Demands.
Other Unions Coming to the Front
With Promises of Assist
ance.
The striking printers claim tn have
made a slight gain, as it was stated yes
terday piat one more office had conceded
to the new scale of prices and had put
on a small force of union men to work
the nine houA at the same wages for
merly paid for ten. The Typothetae con
tradicts this statement emphatically and
claims that if there be any advantage it
is on its side of the house. None of the
offices are working with as large a force
as i dry carried last week, but that is ex
plained by the fact that the shops were
pushed to their full capacity to clear out
the old orders, and what orders have been
received since that time will be held back
as long as possible in the hope of a
speedy settlement of the difficulties.
Mr. Crocker said yesterday that a man
up north had wired him to the effect that
he had fifty men ready to ship down at
once, but he had .informed him that all
he wanted was three good pressmen, and
these were immediately sent to him.
They all proved to be competent men.
A story was published in a morning
paper yesterday to the effect that the old
hands had gone back in three offices at
the old scale of wages, but this is most
emphatically denied at the union head
quarters and notice was posted on the
bulletin board to the effect that the en
tire story was woven out of a tlssue-of
lies and the outlook was very encourWg
ing. To further strengthen this the em
ployes of two of the offices in question
appeared at headquarters and issued a
statement that "they were not working,
have not been working and will not re
sume work for the firm in question or any
other firm until the nine-hour work day
is conceded, and most respectfully and
.- trenuously protest against being placed
in a false position by any one." The of
fice where the men were reported to have
gone back, that of Upton Brothers, em
ployed live printers previous to the strike,
and but two of these, the foreman and
his brother, are now working. A mem
ber of the Typothetae is authority for
the statement that this foreman received
$24 per week previous to the strike, but is
now working for $15.
At the meeting of the Labor Council
last night the strike was the chief topic
and the paper which published the al
leged misleading statement was de
nounced in the bitterest terms. The dele
gates were Instructed to call the atten
tion of their respective unions to this
story and have action taken on it of such
a decisive nature that it will in future
publish labor items in a fair and impar
tial manner.
W. J. McArthur of the Sailors' Union
reported that he had received a commis
sion as organizer for the Western States
for the A. F. of L., and. as this would
take him to Utah during May he would
willingly represent the council at the
Western Miners' Association, to be held
in Salt Lake City early in that month.
He was granted credentials.
The varnishers and polishers also met
last evening and resolved to tender their
unqualified support to the printers in
their struggle and to do all in their power
to aid the cause both as an association
and as individuals.
Union No. 22, Carpenters and Joiners,
met last night and indorsed the action of
the printers in the heartiest manner. This
union has nearly 500 members, and when
a resolution was offered tendering the
full and unqualified support of the union
to tne printers it was carried unanimous
ly. The recognition which the card issued
by the Building Trades Council is meet
ing was also considered a matter for con
gratulation.

AT RECREATION PARK.
Recreation Park will be given over to
the university teams to-day, when Stan
ford and California will play the first of
a series of three games. To-morrow
Fresno will make its first appearance
here, going against the San Franciscoa
of the California League.

WANTS CALIFORNIA THEBE.
Special Commissioner B. W. Bichard
son Here for the Trans-Miss
issippi Exposition.
R. W. Richardson, a prominent lawyer
of Omaha and special commissioner to
California from the Trans-Mississippi
Exposition, is at the Palace, where he
arrived last night on the overland.
Mr. Richardson is here to see if he can
not interest the people of California,
through their Governor and large mer
cantile bodies, in the exposition he rep
resents. He wants the people here to
take active steps to see that their State,
which is the only State west of the Mis
sissippi that has not already done so, ba
fully as well represented at the exposi
tion as the others.
Mr. Richardson says he is not here in
the endeavor to raise or ask for money.
He wishes no appropriation for site or
buildings. All that will be taken care of
by the exposition authorities. He merely
wants the Chamber of Commerce, the
Mining Bureau, together with the Gov
ernor and other public and influential
officials, to use their influence to have all
the different industries of the State well
represented.
Mr. Richardson will probably remain
here several weeks.

1112
THE LOST GIRL
SHOWED UP
Finished in Front of a
Good Field at Nerv
ous Odds.
Tha Southern Colt Ojai Too
Fast for a Band of
Youngsterj.
Charles Le Bel Scored In a Fierce
Driveâ Favorites Went by the
Board.
The "run for Riley races" have com
menced. Lost Girl at odds of Bto 1
won a mile and a sixteenth race at
Oakland yesterday ridden by young
Gray, and the running of some of the
horses behind her would furnish an
Interesting set of kinetoscope views.
Thorpe's honesty can be vouched for,
but he rode a supremely ridiculous race
aboard the favorite, Earl Coohran, and
6ome mornins will awaken to find him
self no longer the idol of the far west
ern turf. H. Martin on Paul Pry, con
sidered the "dangerous horse." got into
all. sorts >if mix-ups during the jour
ney, getting along In time to be beaten
a neck by the Sobrante mare in 1:48^.
If the race was a "shoo in," it was a
cleverly managed arrangement.
The racing throughout the afternoon
was replete with upsets, Merry Boy
and Sweet Faverdale being the only
favorites to take purses.
The talent mad^ T.wanda a mild fa
vorite for the opening seven-furlong
run, but though she had the advantage
of "Skeets" Martin's riding, she found
the distance too far. The race resulted in
Charles Le Bel, Octuruck, Elsmore and
Duke of York finishing heads on the
â wire In the order named. Le Bel. the
winner, ridden by Thorpe, went to the
post at odds of 5 to 1.
A cheap band of "crabs" started in
the mile selling run following. Merry
Boy, the 13 to 5 favorite, with <\ish
Sloan up, won off from Tom Smith, a
7 to 1 chance. Mirambo was a fair
third. Zaraida. backed from 12 down
to 3, blew up in the run home.
OJal, a fast son <>f the Southern Cali
fornia sire, Sid, took trie three and a
half furlong scramble for two-year-olds
In a head finish from Banewor, the
Burns & Waterhouse entry. The pair
were in front from the start, but the
former had a higher turn of speed and
won out in the last jump. Sweet Cakes,
the favorite, away none too well, fin
ished a close third. The winner was
3 to 1 around post time.
It took vigorous riding on the part of
Thorpe to get Sweet Faverdale home
winner of the fifth event, over one mile
and a sixteenth. The mare was equal
choice in the ring with Song ami Dance
and after the latter and Amelia Fonso
had pet the pace to the bend for the
wire. Thorpe began riding the brown
mare and. extended to the last ounce,
downed Plan less than a length. Holmes
by poor riding threw away the place
with Watomba.
In the final six-furlong run. Sport
McAllister, the favorite, and Lucky
Star, the second choice, had it all their
own way from the start. In a hard
drive. Ptufflet on the latter earned thÂ«
verdict by a head. Miss Ruth at en
ticing odds was third.

THE FIGHT OVER
CURRY'S PAYROLL
His Deputies Win the First
Round in the Legal
Scrimmage.
Time Given to the City and County
to Amend the Original
Pleadings.
Judges Hebbard, Belcher and Cook sat
in bank yesterday to hear the injunction
proceedings brought in the nime of the
city and county restraining Auditor Brod
erick from signing the demands of cer
tain copyists and extra register clerks
employed in County Clerk Curry's office
in alleged violation of law.
A demurrer was interposed to the com
plaint on the ground that the pleadings
were Improperly drawn, and it was fur
ther asked that the temporary injunction
issued at the time of the filing of the suit
be dissolved.
Ex-Judge Slack, T. D. Riordan and A.
L. Hart appeared in support of the de
murrer, and the interests of the city and
county were looked after by City and
County Attorney Creawell and Deputy
City and County Attorney Brobeck.
The argument of the law points involved
occupied over two hours, and at its con
clusion the Judges decided to sustain tne
demurrer.
The plaintiff, through Deputy Brobeck,
thereupon asked for time in which to
amend the complaint. He. was according
ly granted until next Tuesday morning in
which to file the amended pleadings, and
in the meantime the temporary injunction
originally issued will remain in force and
effect.
Now Out of Harm's Way.
James Barry, an Incorrigible petty thief,
was sentenced by Judge Cook yesterday
to two and a half years' Imprisonment at
San Quentfn on his plea of guilty to a
charge of felony.
Orezzi Salvini. a youth of 15, who has
a soaring ambition to become a bold, bad
burglar, was sent to the Whlttler Reform
School.
George Morton was sent to Folsom for
four years for burglary.
A New Transfer Company.
Articles of incorporation of the San
Francisco Transfer Company were filed
yesterday by F. S. Chadbourne. J. J.
Gaffney. Lemuel H. Lucas, A. W. John
son and Tborras Hotriclngs.
â  m Â»
RING & BAKKH. 1301 Market street,
sell '-STANDARD"- shirts. â¢
THE SAX FRANCISCO CALL, SATURDAY, APRIL 9, 1898.
ICE BOUND
WHALERS IN
NEED OFHELP
Continued from Second Page.
a 600-ton steamer and barge at Its ship
yard. The Canadian Pacific is also
building a river boat to carry 350 tons
of freight on thirty-inch draught. The
Alaska Exploration Company had Its
barges on the beach and was putting
up a large building to be used as a
hotel.
The gasoline yacht El Irena had been
hauled on the beach and her passen
gers were in very comfortable quarters.
There was a large migration to Mi
nook. I could not learn of any actual
discoveries, but every one who could
get a dog team was going over the por
tage, and some poor fellows were drag
ging their sleighs along on foot heav
ily loaded.
L. B. Shepherd had discovered
a coal mine about ten miles be
low Unanacluk, which will no doubt
prove a bonanza. The coal is consid
ered first-class steam coal, and lies on
the coast, so that with the necessary
appliances, which are now being put
in place, the whalers and revenue cut
ters can get their coal handily and
ships will have good protection and sea.
He will also be able to supply thÂ«
river steamers with coal. There will
be nearly fifty steamers on the Yukon
next year, and there will be a famine
as regards wood, so this find will prove
of great value. It was reported that
flour was worth $10 per sack of fifty
pounds at Neulattes, but I did not
learn of any new diggings in this quar
ter.
Dr. Edie, who had been attending to
Cannuanwar's case, pronounced her fit
to travel, so I got a small quantity of
provisions from the people and left St.
Michael on the 16th day of January,
with my colors set. The different sta
tions dipped their flags as I started and
fired volley after volley of rifles, pistols
and let off three dynamite blasts. I
had taken with me Mr. James' guide,
Kohltoph by name.
He showed m,e the road from St.
Michael to Kodak, also accompanying
{ me to my first stopping place, which
! was E. H. Hanson's, former manager
lof Wright, Bowne & Co. We reached
the steamer J. J. Healy, lying at winter
â¢ quarters at Indian Canal, where I
j stopped for the night.
She is under command of Captain
Harry Lott, formerly of Port Town
send. Our party was very pleasantly
| entertained by her officers, Messrs. An
; derson and McCorker. We also vitited
; the steamer Mare Island, and all her
passengers seemed to feel in good spir
its. A great many of them had se
; cured work in St. Michael, and there
J were only about twenty-five left on
i board.
From Kodiak down the coast to Port
land the trip was without particular
incident.
The Wasp This Week.
The pictorial features of the Wasp this
week are varied and of general interest.
One of the principal subjects is a page
of splendid half-tone engravings of the
I'nited States ships Monterey and Monad
nock, the battle-ships which, in case of
war. wili be called upon to protect the
Pacific Coast. There are also pictures of
several prominent persons in social and
political life. The center-page cartoon,
depicting the "Brewing of the Hell
Broth" by the pretended patriots of New
York yellow journalism, is an especially
clever composition. Ihe editorials on the
stirring topics of the day are vigorous
and well written and the various depart
ments are worthy of careful perusal. Al
together this week's Wasp is a particu
larly interesting number and bears out
its reputation as the leading weekly jour
nal of the Paoillc Coast.
A New Easter Mass Will Be Sung.
The mass to be sung at St. Charles
Church to-morrow morMing in honor of
the resurrection of the Redeemer is the
composition of H. J. Schonacker of In
dianapolis, Ind.. a brother to Mrs. Hay,
the present organist of the church. This
will be the first time that the mass has
ever been sung In public and consequently
much interest is manifested by local crit
ics, who are anxious to pass judgment
upon it. The final rehearsal, with voices
and instrumental accompaniment, was
held last Thursday evening and proved
a success.
THE STOCK MARKET.
There was a sharp drop In mining stocks on
the afternoon call, as will be seen by the list
of sales.
Yellow Jacket Is assessed 20 cents.
The Hale & Noroross and Occidental assess
monts fall delinquent In board to-day.
Local securities were weak on the Bond
Exchange. Oceanic Steamship sold own to
$00. Gas and Klectric to $84 50 and Hawaiian
Cnmmerlcal to $24 50.
The Llllle mine of Colorado paid a dividend
of $9000 on the Ist.
The Moon-Anchor mine of Colorado paid a
dividend of $15,000 on the 2d.
The Horn Silver mine of Utah paid a divi
dend of 5 cents per share, or $20,000, on the
Ist. Hereafter quarterly dividends at the same
rate will lie paid.
The official letter from the Justice mine for
the past week says: "Work in the winze from
the face of the southeast drift has been tem
porarily suspended on account of water. The
seepage Is now decreasing rapidly, and we ex
pect to resume work In the winze by the lat
ter part of the week. On the SO-foot level we
have timbered the north drift a distance of
25 feet, and are now stoping ore from the face
This ore has widened and now shows a width
of five feet. We have hoisted seven tons <>i
ore from this stope during the week. The car
samples of the ore average, gold $32 41, silver
$21 OH; total, $53 50 per ton."
Payment of the six months' interest on its
bonded indebtedness due on the Ist, has been
passed by the Pan Francisco Breweries, Lim
ited. The amount involved Is $75,000

1314
MOURNED
THE SAVIOR'S
SACRIFICE
Good Friday Solemnly
Observed by the
Churches.
Sermons, Chanting, Lit
anies and Readings
From St. John.
Beautiful Wgeather and a Great
Attendance at All the
Services.
SIMPLICITY THE CUSTOM.
An Absence of Mxisio and Many Evi
dences of Sorrowful De
votion.
Good Friday services were observed
in even- church in the city yesterday,
noticeably in the Roman Catholic and
Episcopal. Owing to the beautiful
weather the attendance at all services
was large, and a noticeable feature in
the Catholic ranks was quite a revival
of the old custom of making pilgrim
ages from one churc' to another. Hun
dred* of the faithful observed this cus
tom.
Throughout the halcyon afternoon
there was the greatest silence in all the
churches. Not a bell rang, not an or
gan Bounded, but chanting and prayer
marked the day.
In the Catholic churches solemn de
votional servici took the place of the
solemnization of the mass in the morn
ing, while the evening services consist
ed not of the observance of vespers and
benediction but of the saying of the
rosary and sermons on the subject of
'"The Passion" as recorded in St. John.
Services in all *the churches of the
city were marked by great simplicity,
as is usual. In the Catholic churches
the altars and ofiiciatin- clergy were
draped in black. Go d Friday being the
only day when such draping occurs.
Prayers for peace and the unity of the
church, for the rulers of the nation and
state, were general iv offered.
Another feature of the observance of
the day in the Catholic churches was
that the clergy removed their shoes
during part of the ceremonies, and the
eucharist was taken out of the taber
nacle and placed on St. Joseph's altar,
where it will remain until to-day in all
the churches.
After the reading of the ceremonies
the choirs chanted without the aid of
any organ music, which was abolished.
Some of the clergy chanted and others
chanted the answers. After the cere
monies the crucifix was taken to the
altar, and the congregation in front of
the altar rail kissed the wounds, the
crucifix being on a cushion in front of
the altar steps.
At St. Ignatius the afternoon ceremo
nies lasted three hours, the Rev.
Father Xeri <' Mvering a sermon on
"The Last Seven Words of Christ."
The Episcopal services throughout
the city were quite impressive, consist
ing of the usual Good Friday ceremo
niee. At Grace Church the ceremonies
began at 10:30 and consisted' of the
prayer, litany and sermon by Rev. Dr.
Foute. The afternoon services contin
ued from 3 until 6 o'clock. They consist
ed of continuous services and addresses
by several ministers. The nieht services
began at 8 o'clock and were conducted
by Rev. Dr. Shaw.
There were special services at the
First Lutheran Church yesterday
morning. The Rev. E. E. Nelander de
livered a Bennon, subject "Before the
Cross." The servic s also Included a
select number of solos and other sine
ing by the choir.
In other churches throughout the
city the services were of a similar
character, consisting largely of the
reading of passages from St. John and
the observance of the formalities long
prescribed in the various denomina
tions.
Money Coining In.
Manager J. A. Filcher. who Is handling
the Alaska trade end of the State Board
rf Trade, In speaking A the work of col
lecting money for advertising purposes,
said: Mayor Phelan has set a pood ex
ample to the capitalists and business men
of San Francisco by sending In a subscrip
tion of $25 a month, with the first month
In advance, toward the support of the
Btate Board of Trade, for the purpose of
strengthening Its endeavors to secure as
much of the Alaska trade as possible for
Ban Francisco. There are certainly fifty
men and firms in this large city who can
afford to do as well, and a hundred others
who can giv^ $r> or more a month- and
with from $1000 to $20K) a month properly
expended. Manager Filcher says, the civ
ilized world could be aroused to San
FrandÃeo's advantages as a great sea
port and outfitting point, aDd a large
share of the Alaska trade, especially that
by way of the Yukon, which will soon
commence, could b* turned this way
An Advance in Through Rates.
Vice-President J. C. Stubbs of the
Bouthern Pacific received a telegram yes
terday from New York, Informing him
that all the lines involved in the passen
ger rate war had decided to advance the
rates from the Missouri River to Pacific
Coast terminals $10 on both first and sec
ond class fares. This will make the rate
to Portland, Seattle and Vancouver $30
first-class and $110 second-class.
The telegram was received late In the
afternoon and was unaccompanied by any
other information. It is supposed to bo

AN IMPORTANT CONFERENCE.
A Committee From the Merchants'
Association Talk Paving With
H. E. Huntington.
A committee from the Merchants' Asso
ciation of San Francisco held a consulta-.
tion with H. E. Huntington of the Mar
ket-street Railroad Company at the lat
ter's office yesterday afternoon relative
to the proposed repaying of Market
street. Owing to the terms of the fran
chise under which the railroad company
operates It is responsible for nearly one
half the expense of the proposed im
provements, while the balance of the ex
penditure would have to be borne by the
city. The meeting was behind closed doors
and was an exceedingly lengthy one,
but it was learned that after the whole
matter had been thoroughly talked over
the most Mr. Huntington could say was
that the matter would be considered by
the board of directors at a special meet
ing which will be called for that purpose
either this afternoon or Monday morning.
Those present at yesterday's conference
were Mayor Phelan. Hugo Kiel. A. S.
Baldwin and W. R. Sherwood, represent
ing the Merchants' Association, and H. E.
Huntington, representing the Market
street Railroad Company. Henry H.
Lynch, superintendent of construction for
the railroad people, was called in to give
his advice on some technical matters that
came up.
â  â¦ â 
PRAISE FOR POLICEMEN.
Fire Marshal Towe Compliments
Officers R. J. McGrayan and
J. Lynch.
Fire Marshal Charles Towe has paid a
well-deserved compliment to Policemen R.
J. McGrayan and J. Lynch. The compli
ment was given in a communication to
Captain of Police John Spillane. and by
him referred to the Police Commission-
ers before it was transmitted to the offi
cers named. The Fire Marshal in his
communication tells of a fire In the early
morning in a restaurant that was dis
covered by Policeman McGrayan. wno
promptly gave an alarm and as promptly
went to the rescue of over a score of
persons who were sleeping over the store
where the flames were discovered and
who were in peril of their lives. "I be
lieve.' said the Fire Marshal, "that
through the promptness of the officer a
calamity was averted â one that would
have sent a thrili through the hearts of
our best citizens."
Fire Marshal Towe not only thanked
Policeman McGrayan, but extended a
word of praise to Policeman J. Lynch.
He says that It was through the combined
efforts and good Judgment of McGrayan
and Lynch that he was able to procure
evidence that established the fact that
the place had purposely been set on fire,
and which will bring the perpetrators of
the crime to the bar of justice.
"How little thought our citizens give
to such brave deeds I know full well,"
concludes the Fire Marshal; "but it is
such acts that cause me to know the
vni'ip of the ever watchfulness of our
police."
To Investigate a Nuisance.
The members of the Board of Health
and Mayor Phelan will drive out to the
Lick and Wilmerding schools site this
morning and investigate the nuisance
property-owners in the vicinity allege ex
ists there. Four blocks bounded by San
Bruno avenue. Kansas, Sixteenth and
Channel streets are far below the official
grade and are covered with stagnant
water, which is considered a menace to
the health of those living in the vicinity.
CHINESE EMBEZZLER CAPTURED
Deputy Sheriff Q. H. Kinloch of So-
lano Lands a Daring Criminal.
Deputy Sheriff G. H. Kinloch of Solano
County cleverly captured Yee Wing, a
well-known highbinder, and after some
trouble brought him to the City Prison
last evening, where a charge of felony
embezzlement was entered against him.
Wing embezzled a large sum of money
from a fellow-Chinaman and succeeded
In leaving the city, despite the effort of
the police to find him. He skipped to So
lano County, and his whereabouts be
came known to the local officers. A war
rant for his arrest was forwarded to
Kinloch, who after a long search found
him. Wing's presence in the country
town waa kept secret by his countrymen,
and every effort was made to prevent
Kinloch from effecting his capture.

SOME OF THE ENTRIES FOR THE GREAT RACE TO-DAY.
winner at all sorts of odds in the bet
ting.
When the weights for the race this
afternoon were first issued much fault
i was found with the allotments made by
: Handicapper Brooks, and not without
j some reason, for several good horses
| will remain in the stables on account
iof the heavy imposts dealt out with
j lavish hand. However, a field of eleven
j horses have accepted the issue, and,
! from a betting standpoint, it promises
! to be a swell affair, as nearly every
! horse is conceded a chance by enthu-
I elastic admirers.
There is a paucity of riding material,
and the officials of the California
! Jockey Club have been called upon to
unravel many perplexing entangle
ments, every available jockey appar
ently having engaged himself to at
least two different owners. This prob
lem is now settled, and the make-up of

i Marplot. 94, J. Woods.
Morelllto. 104, Spencer.

1-lnstock. 107. Gray
Scarborough, US, Hennessy.
In a prominent downtown hotel, the
resort of horsemen, the betting last
evening favored the Burns & Water
house pair. Traverser and Candelaria,
at odds of 7to 2. The quotations
against the others were: Scarborough,
E to 1; Ostler Joe, 7 to 1; Won't Dance,
10 to 1; Satsuma, 10 to 1; Buck Massie,
7 to 1; Fonsovannah, 12 to 1; Marplot,
30 to 1; Linstock. 8 to 1; Morellito, 10
to 1. At these odds Scarborough and
Ostler Joe seemed most in demand.
The race has created widespread en
thusiasm, and the largest crowd of the
present racing season promises to be
present.
THE DIRECTORY CROWDED.
Not Room for One-half the Youths
Who Desire AdmissionâPlan
ning a New Building.
Finding that the old building at 2023
Howard street is no longer adequate for
the purposes, Father Crowley intends
erecting a new building to be used as the
Youths' Directory.
The Youths' Directory was founded
eleven years ago, at which time Father
Crowley purchased the lot on Howard
street, which then contained a twelve
room house. For a time this was large
enough, but so rapidly did the institution
grow that at the end of a year the old
building was moved back in the yard and
the present building was erected.
It is proposed to erect the new bui.^mg
on Nineteenth street, between Valencia
and Guerrero. It will be a handsome
structure of the Italian Renaissance
style, built in the shape of an "L," and,
although it will front on Nineteenth
street, the main building will oe on An
gelica street, with 173 feet resting on
Cumberland place.
A new building has become an absolute
necessity, as the f ur large dormitories
have become overeiowdedâ two boys oc
cupying each bed, and the beds were
meant for only one. As the Directory is
supported almost entirely by voluntary
contributions, it has no fund on hand to
erect the new building, the cost of wMcli
is estimated at $80,000, and Father Crow
ley will appeal to the public for money to
aid in the work.
Will Damage Their Property.
George Brown and a half dozen other
owners of property on Turk street, be
tween Masonic avenue and St. Joseph's
avenue, commenced suit yesterday
against Mayor Phelan, the Board of
Supervisors and Archbishop Rirodan, to
onjoln them from carrying out the terms
of a resolution passed "by the Supervisors
providing for the reduction of the width
of Turk street 31 feet 3 inches between
the above-named avenues. They allege
that if the resolution is put into effect it
will result in serious damage to their
property.
Election Commissioners.
The Election Commissioners met yester
day and ordered the publication of the
proclamation calling for the special char
ter election on May 26 Bids were or
dered advertised for for the erection of
the polling booths, supplies, etc.; also
bids for the printing of the new precinct
maps. In compliance with the written re
quest of the Carpenters' Union the board
adopted a resolution providing that the
successful bidder for erecting the elec
tion booths shall not work his men more
than eight hours a day, and providing for
a fine of $7f> for each violation of the or
der and the forfeiture of the contract.
FOUND HIM UNCONSCIOUS.
Officers Looking for a Man Find Him
With a Fractured Skull.
A. C. Sloan, who was wanted by the po
lice, was found by Officers Prowse and
Jewell last evening lying unconscious in
the street at the corner of Jackson and
Dupont streets. He was taken to the
Harbor Receiving Hospital, where he was
found to be bleeding from the ear and an
investigation showed that his skull had
been fractured. The man was under the
influence of liquor and became so violent
t J? at . lt Wiis necssary to remove him to
the hospital at the City Hall and place
him in a padded cell.
Sloan is supposed to have stolen a box
of tobacco from Horn & Co., at 205 Bat
tery street, yesterday afternoon. The to
bacco was sold to a cigar dealer at the
corner of Montgomery and Washington
streets, and from the buyer's description
of the man who sold it the officers think
Sloan the guilty man. He is well known
to the police as a bad character, and it is
their opinion that while drunk from the
money he received for the stolen goodu
he fell and injured himself.
Cosmos Club Election.
ThÂ© annual election of officers of the
Cosmos Club will be neld to-day, and the
old question of a ladies' annex will t rob
ably he finally settled as the result of this
ballot. The candidates favoring this an
nex are W. B. Bradford, president, and
James T. Langhorn vice-president. At
the head of the opposition are Ferdinand
Reis for president and John Alexander
for vice-president. It is probable that the
election will be warmly contested, as
much interest is felt in the matter.
Loring Club Concert.
The Loring Club will give Its third con
cert at Odd Fellows 1 Hall next Wednes
day evening. The programme, which has
many interesting numbers. Is as follows:
"Sea Greeting," Thayer; "Far Away "
Engelberg; trio, piano, violin and violon-
cello (Op. 99), Schubert; "Night Greet
ing," Kremser; "The Merry Trumpeter,"
Rhelnberger: "Heinz yon Stein," Thayer;
'cello solo, "Caprice Hongrolse," Roerer;
"Spring Magic, Sturm; violin solo, (a)
"Cavatina," Sauret; (b) "Perpetuum Mo
bile," Scharwenka; "To the Sons of Art,"
Mendelssohn.
Rotten Sidewalks.
Property-owners on Sanchez street, be
tween Market and Fourteenth, have filed
with the Supervisors a protest against
the acceptance of the sidewalks recently
put down by Flinn & Treacy. They allege
that the wrong kind of rock was used;
that the bitumon was not properly cook
ed; that the walks will not permit water
to drain off. and that the top dressing is
so rotten that it can be crumbled with
the fingers.
He Now Hopes to Live.
Charley Dean, the half-breed Chinese,
who shot and killed Ah Gow. a Chinese
woman, is not so desirous of making a
hero of himself on the scaffold as he was
two weeks ago. At that time he pleaded
guilty. When he was brought before
Judge Wallace yesterday he asked per
mission to withdraw his plea of guilty in
cider that he might stand trial. The plea
was withdrawn, and the 2Sth inst. was
set for the beginning of the trial.
The Verdict Was Excessive.
The Bowers Rubber Company recently
recovered judgment lor $4000 against H.
D. Blasdel. A motion for a new trial
was made, and Judge Hunt yesterday de
ciaed that the verdict of the jury was
excessive. In a written opinion filed.
Judge Hunt set forth his views of the
litigation, concluding with the announce
ment that he believed $600 would fully
compensate the plaintiffs. Unless they
accept that amount a new trial will be
granted.
Still Fighting for Alimony.
Frankle White. ...e divorced wife of
George E. White, the "cattle king" of
Mendocino County, commenced suit yes
terday against Hulme & Hart to enjoin
them from paying $'1500 to her former hus
band. She has for months past been light
ing to secure the payment of back ali
mony, and now sues to enjoin Hulme &
Hart, having received information that
her divorced husband holds a claim
against them for $1500.
